Income paid by an insurance company to a retired self-employed insurance broker in proportion to the commission received before retirement is reported in Schedule C. In addition, renewal fees and severance fees for sales made before retirement are generally reported in Schedule C. However, renewal fees paid to the surviving spouse of an insurance broker are not reported in Schedule C.
This applies regardless of whether a minimum income is guaranteed, or whether you receive a commission for returning unsold newspapers or magazines to your supplier.

The accounting of income for income tax purposes is sometimes different from accounting for financial purposes. This section describes the more general differences that can affect business transactions. Business income is determined according to the standard accounting method based on tax years (see Chapter 2). When a product seller is a factor in generating income in a business, it is usually necessary to use assets to clearly indicate income.
All income you earn is taxed to you, and you can't avoid paying taxes by paying income to a third party.

We must use the method we choose each year for all purchases. If we use the second method, the account balance at the end of the tax year is business income. In this method, we cannot deduct the cash discount price from the sales price. When we evaluate the final inventory, we cannot reduce the forwarding price of the goods we hold at the end of the tax year by the average or estimated value of the goods.

An asset purchaser that places some or all of the purchase price into escrow does not include that portion of the sale in the gross sales amount until it actually or approximately receives the asset, but the contract terms and the escrow agreement are completed and there is taxable income even if the asset is not paid until the following year.

This chapter applies if the person is a manufacturer, wholesaler, or retailer, or is engaged in a business of manufacturing, buying, or selling goods to generate income. This chapter does not apply to a personal service business, such as a doctor, lawyer, carpenter, or merchant, but to a business of selling or billing supplies and materials commonly used in the business, as a person engaged in the business of providing personal services. There are exceptions for small business taxpayers, which may result in a change in the reseller of supplies for the business.

If you are a seller, use the cost of all goods purchased for sale. If you are a manufacturer or producer, this includes the cost of all raw materials or components purchased for the manufacture of the finished product.

The difference between the stated price of the item and the price you actually pay is called the purchase discount. You should use the price you pay (not the stated price) to figure out the purchase cost. You don't show the discount as a separate item in gross income. The car broker should record the reduced car cost in the manufacturer's rebate, which represents the purchase discount.

The cash discount is the amount that the supplier can deduct from the purchase receipt for a quick payment. There are two accounting methods for the cash discount: the amount can be deposited into a separate discount account or deducted from the total sales for the year. Either method should be consistent. To change the accounting method for inventory, please submit Form 3115, Application for Change of Accounting Method, and the Annuity Statement, for more details.

If you are acquiring goods for personal or family use, you must deduct this cost from the total amount of goods you purchased for sale. The cost of goods acquired for personal use is represented in the purchase or sales account. You must also set aside the corresponding amount in the receipt account.
In manufacturing, the cost of labor that can be appropriately allocated to a salesperson includes both direct labor and indirect labor used to manufacture raw materials into finished products.

Direct labor costs are the salaries paid to employees who spend all of their time working directly on the product being manufactured, and also include the portion of their salaries paid to employees who work part-time on the product itself, if that portion of their salary can be determined.

Indirect labor costs are salaries paid to employees who perform normal factory tasks that are not directly or indirectly related to the production of a marketable product, but are an essential part of the manufacturing process.

The container and the packaging, which are an essential part of the manufactured product, are part of the cost of the product, and if they are not an essential part of the manufactured product, then the cost is the shipping or selling cost.

Indirect costs include costs such as rent, heating, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor, and supervision. Indirect costs held as direct and necessary costs in manufacturing operations are included in the cost of revenue.

If the sale of goods is not a factor in generating income for your business, you do not need to calculate the revenue source. The gross profit is equal to the net sales (the amount of cashback, discounts, or other annuities deducted from gross sales). Most professions and businesses that sell services rather than products can figure out the direct gross profit from net sales in this way.

At the end of each business day, check that the actual cash and credit card receipts for the day match the balance. It may be helpful to use a cash machine to track sales. Also, use a proper remittance system and maintain a separate bank account for your business.

If you, as the seller of a good or service, collect state and local sales taxes levied on you from a buyer, you must include the amount of the tax withheld in your gross income. If you collect state and local taxes levied on a buyer and pay them to the state or local government, then these amounts are generally not included in your income.

So you run a retail company, and on average, you're trying to make a profit on your product, and you're trying to make a profit on your gross sales of 331/3%. So the net sales (the amount of cash in the gross sales minus the annuity) on the profit and loss account is $300,000. So the revenue is $200,000. So that's $100,000. So that's gross sales of $100,000.

If your business has other sources of income than regular business operations, enter the income on line 6 of Schedule C and add it to gross profit and loss. The result is gross operating income. Some examples include income from accounts that pay interest, income from the sale of scrap metal, income from certain fuel tax deductions and refunds, and the amount recovered from your property damage.

If you are a self-employed person, you can deduct your contributions to the plan for you from Schedule 1 (Form 1040) on line 16. You can also deduct your contributions to the plan if you are unable to pay the withdrawal fee with your contributions to this plan. Income from your contributions is generally tax-deductible until you or your employee receive a distribution from that plan. If you have a new qualified expansion plan or an expansion plan with an expansion plan (401k) account, you can also apply for a tax credit for that account if you start a SIMP or SEPLE plan.

Rent is the amount you pay for the use of an asset that you do not own. Generally, rent is deductible as a business expense only if it is the asset that the business uses. If you have a share or ownership interest in the asset, you cannot deduct the rent.

Generally, the rent paid for a business is deducted for the year in which it is paid or incurred. If you pre-giveaway the rent, you can deduct only the amount applicable to the use of the rental property during the tax year, and the rest can be deducted only during the period in which it is applicable.

You may deduct state income taxes on gross income (as distinguished from net income) attributable directly to the business on Schedule C. For itemized deductions, you may deduct other state and local income taxes on Schedule A (Form 1040). Do not deduct federal income taxes.

As an employer, you can deduct Social Security, Medicare, and FUTA payments from your own funds. Employment taxes are briefly discussed in Chapter 1. As an employer, you can deduct amounts paid to your state unemployment benefit fund or state disability benefit fund. You deduct these payments as taxes.

You can deduct any taxes levied by state or local governments on personal property used for business or on Schedule C, or you can deduct registration fees for the right to use the property within the state or region.

You may deduct property taxes you pay on commercial real estate from your income on Schedule C. Deductible property taxes are state, local, or foreign taxes on real estate that are imposed for the benefit of the general public. The taxing agency must assess these taxes at the same rate for all properties under its jurisdiction, and the proceeds must be for general community or government purposes.

If the cost or use of the service or asset is a tax deductible business expense, then the tax may be deducted as part of the cost of the service or expense. If the asset is purchased for resale, the tax is part of the cost of the goods. If the asset is depreciable, the tax is added to the base price for depreciation. For information on the base price of the asset, see Publication 551. State and local sales taxes imposed on the purchaser, which you must pay to the state or local government, are not deducted.

The following costs may be deducted: advertising expenses; bank fees; donations to business organizations; training expenses; damage-related expenses; interview expenses; allowances; licensing and regulatory fees; machine relocation; re-employment notice services; a retainer for delayed performance or non-performance of a contract; repair and maintenance for tangible or intangible personal property; income returns; spare parts and supplies; utility bills.

In general, the following may not be deducted as business expenses: bribes and kickbacks; charitable donations; demolition costs or losses; business, social, exercise, dinner, sports, airline, and hotel club expenses; meeting fees; tangible or typical personal property improvement costs; the amount you pay for improvements to your property, the restoration of your property, or the conversion of your property to a new use or other use; lobbying expenses; fines paid to a government agency or organization for violating the law; personal, living, and family expenses; political contributions; settlements related to sexual harassment or sexual abuse or the present (if the settlement or payment is the subject of a nondisclosure agreement); and attorneys' expenses related to such settlements or payments.

If you have an uncollectible debt, you have a loss, and there are two types of loss, business loss and non-business loss, and business loss is usually a debt that arises from a transaction or from operating a business, and business loss can be deducted as an expense on your business tax return.

If the principal motivation for the debt is a business reason, the debt is closely related to your business. The business loss is mainly the result of credit sales to customers. It may also be the result of loans to suppliers, customers, employees or distributors. Goods and services that are not paid by the customer are shown to the Ministry of Finance as arrears or arrears. If the bank is unable to collect these arrears or arrears, the bank is responsible for the loss of business.

If you claim a loss allowance on your income tax return and later recover all or part of the loss allowance, you may be required to include all or part of the recovered amount in your gross income. The amount included is limited to the amount actually recovered. However, the amount of the recovered amount that has not been deducted may be excluded. Please report the amount of the recovered amount as Other income on the appropriate business form or schedule.

If you use the accrual method of accounting, you generally report your income when you raise your income. If you include your unpaid sales receivables in your income, you may be entitled to a loss allowance for the unpaid amount.

If you use cash accounting, you generally report your income when you receive the payment. If you do not include the amount you did not receive and cannot withdraw, you will not be entitled to a full indemnity for the amount you owe.
If the security or collateral is sold for less than the bond, the outstanding balance of the bond is a loss.

If the bond is sold for a higher amount than the principal, the gain on the sale is due to the increase in value of the property in question. This is not the recapture of the loss on the sale. For information on the sale of the asset, see Interlocutory 544.

The standard mileage rate cannot be used if: 1. you operate more than five cars at the same time; 2. you have used a method other than the semen method to deduct depreciation (e.g., ACRS or MACRS); 3. you have charged a Section 179 fee for the vehicle; 4. you have charged a special depreciation allowance for the vehicle; 5. you have charged actual vehicle costs for the leased vehicle; or 6. you are a rural mail carrier who has received a qualified refund.

If the assets acquired for use in your business are expected to last for more than one year, then you generally cannot deduct the full cost of the acquisition from the business expense for the year. You must spread the expense over more than one tax year and deduct a portion of it from Schedule C each year. The method of deducting the cost of these business assets is called depreciation.

It must be an asset that you own, that you use for business or that you hold to generate income. It must never be depreciable (as explained in Chapter 2) because it is not held for use in your business. It must have a useful life that is far beyond the years of service. It must have a definite useful life, that is, it must be something that has become worn out, rotten, worn out, become useless, or lose its value from natural causes. It must not be possible to depreciate the cost of land because it is not wet, aged, or depreciable. It must not be an exceptional asset. This includes services disposed of in the same year and disposed of assets.

In a transaction or business, an option may be used to treat a particular repair or replacement as an improvement subject to depreciation or amortization. This option may be used when treating these amounts as capital expenditures in the accounts and records that are regularly used to calculate income and expenses.

You will be entitled to receive a tax deduction of $1,220,000 (a higher limit applies to specific assets) for the year 2024. This limit will be reduced by the amount of the cost of the assets in service during the tax year, which will be $3,050,000 (a higher limit applies to specific assets). You will be entitled to receive a tax deduction of $1,220,000 (a higher limit applies to specific assets) for the year 2024. You will be entitled to receive a tax deduction of $1,220,000 (a lower limit applies to specific assets) for the year 2024. You will be entitled to receive a tax deduction of $1,220,000 (a higher limit applies to specific assets) for the year 2024.

If you are claiming any of the following, use Form 4562, Depreciation and amortization, Depreciation for assets in service during the taxable year, Section 179 deduction, Depreciation for all specified assets (irrespective of when the service was opened).

If you have a lease, you may deduct the cost of repairs or other underlying costs from your employee's pay if you have a section 179 deduction or an appraisal deduction. If you have a lease, you may deduct all or part of the repairs you provide from your employee's pay. For more information on the repairs and the benefits excluded, see Publication 15-B.

You may deduct from Schedule C the costs of completing the relevant portion of your tax return related to your business as a sole proprietor or as an employee of the corporation. You may also deduct from Schedule C the amounts paid or incurred to settle a tax liability for your business as a sole proprietor or as an employee of the corporation.

For tax purposes, an alien is an individual who is not a U.S. citizen. An alien is classified as a nonresident alien and a resident alien. This publication helps determine your identity and provides the information you need to file a U.S. tax return. A resident alien is generally taxed on worldwide income from the same source as a U.S. citizen.

The United States suspended the operation of Section 3 (1) (g) of the Agreement. The remaining provisions of the Agreement remain in effect. The suspension of the Agreement entered into force on December 17, 2024, and will continue until December 31, 2026, or until thereafter if mutually determined by the two governments. The suspension of the Agreement with Russia is effective until December 17, 2024, unless the United States Government has notified the Russian Federation that it is suspending the Agreement with Russia. The United States Government has notified the Russian Federation that it is suspending the Agreement with Russia.

Nonresident aliens (and certain resident aliens) from countries with which the United States has an income tax treaty may be eligible for certain benefits. Most treaties stipulate that a nonresident alien must be a resident of a treaty country to be disqualified in the year the benefit is claimed, but some treaties require that in the case of certain students, trainees, teachers, or researchers, the nonresident alien must be a resident of a treaty country immediately prior to entering the United States.

The full text of individual tax treaties is also available at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. For more information about the tax treaties, please visit IRS.gov/individuals/international-tax-payers-treaty-tables. Please note that you are generally entitled to receive tax benefits and other benefits that you may be entitled to receive from the tax treaty. You may be eligible for tax deductions and other benefits that you may be entitled to receive from the tax treaty.

Non-resident alien's treaty income is the total income that is taxed by treaty. Treaty income includes allowances of U.S. origin that are taxed at a treaty tax rate not exceeding, for example, 15%. Non-treaty income is the total income of a non-resident alien that is not taxed by the treaty in question. To calculate the tax on the income item to which the treaty tax rate is applied, calculate the tax on each individual income item at the treaty tax rate applicable to that item.

The following paragraphs briefly describe the exemptions provided under the tax treaty for personal service income, remittances, scholarships, grants, and capital income. The conditions for claiming the exemption vary by tax treaty. For more information on the terms of a particular tax treaty, please download the full text of the U.S. tax treaty at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. A legal description of a number of the treaties is also available at this website. Please also see Publication 901. Tax treaty benefits also include dividends, interest, rent, annuity, annuity, retirement, and dividend distributions.

Under most income tax treaties, nonresident aliens from treaty countries who are temporarily staying in the United States to perform services, and dual-identity residents (see Section 1) who are privileged under the tiebreaker rule with treaty countries, may be eligible to receive some or all of their personal service income exempt from U.S. taxation if they meet the treaty provisions applicable to them.
Some income tax treaties include other requirements, such as a maximum length of stay. For more information, see Publication 901.

Some income tax treaties include an "Independent Personal Service" clause, which allows residents of treaty countries to receive a U.S. tax exemption on income earned as an independent contractor or self-employed individual if they have not resided in the United States for more than a certain number of days and have not had a regular, fixed headquarters in the United States.

Under the income tax treaty, non-resident foreign teachers or professors who visit the United States temporarily for the main purpose of lecturing at a university or other accredited educational institution are not subject to U.S. income tax on their remuneration for lecturing for the first two to three years after arriving in the United States.In addition, several treaties also provide for exemption for those engaged in research.Generally, teachers or professors must stay in the United States for the main purpose of teaching, lecturing, lecturing, or researching.The majority of their personal time should be devoted to these duties.The general duties of teachers or professors include not only formal instructional activities, which may include regularly scheduled lectures, demonstrations, or other student activities, but also presenting ideas in collaboration at informal seminars or other informal groups, such as participating in experiments.If you are a non-resident foreign national entering the United States and now residing in the country, the exemption will still apply after the treaty has been signed.

All treaties have an income exemption for certain foreign government employees, but there are differences between treaties regarding eligibility for these benefits. Under many treaties, foreigners who are U.S. residents are not eligible. Under most treaties, non-citizens or non-citizens of foreign countries are not eligible. Foreign government employees must read the treaty to determine whether they are eligible for benefits.

Under some income tax treaties, remittances received by students, trainees, and apprentices for research and maintenance are exempt from taxation. Also, under some treaties, the amount of scholarships, grants, and limited benefits received by students, trainees, and apprentices are exempt from taxation. If you entered the United States as a nonresident alien but are currently a resident alien, the treaty exemption may still apply.

Most agreements provide for exemption from taxation of gains on the sale and exchange of personal assets, although gains on the sale and exchange of real estate, generally located in the United States, are taxable.

However, there are exceptions to the withholding clause that allow resident aliens to claim the benefits of the Continuing Agreement. Exceptions to some of the withholding clauses apply to all resident aliens (for example, under the United States-China Tax Treaty). Other provisions apply only to non-resident aliens who are not legal permanent residents of the United States (green card holders). Under certain treaties, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or on line 1040-SR for exemption from U.S. taxes.

If you receive a Social Security benefit from Canada or Germany, you must determine the taxable amount and include it in line 1 of the Social Security Benefits Worksheet in the Form 1040 and 1040-SR Guidelines for the purpose of reporting it on line 6b of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. You do not need to file Form 8833 for the benefit in question.

To claim tax treaty exemption for scholarships, grants, and research grants received from abroad for study and residency in the United States, and for benefits for salaries and other personal services, you must generally be a nonresident alien student, trainee, apprentice, teacher, professor, or researcher. As a resident alien, you generally can no longer claim tax treaty exemption for that income. However, if you entered the United States as a nonresident alien but are currently a resident alien for U.S. tax purposes, the treaty's Storage Clause (described below) provides an exemption and the treaty's exemption continues to apply if you meet the foreign treaty exemption requirements (described below, which apply to the treaty exemption claim). As explained in Section 1, the treaty also applies even if you are a nonresident alien who has chosen to file a joint return. If you are an exception to the treaty's provisions, you may be exempt from filing the income taxation required by the W-9 form with the W-9 instruction to the provider of the residency grant.

In certain cases, you do not have to report income on Form 1040 or 1040-SR because you are exempt from U.S. tax under the agreement. However, if the income item was reported as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042, Form 1099, or other information, you must report it on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (for example, line 1a in the case of amounts reported on Form W-2, box 1).

If you are claiming the benefits of a treaty that prioritizes or changes the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, and your taxes are reduced or are likely to be reduced, you must attach a completed Form 8833 to your tax return. Please note that you do not have to file Form 8833 in the following exceptions.

You do not need to file Form 8833 if: 1. you claim withholding tax under the agreement on interest, dividends, rent, royalties, or other FDAP income that would normally be taxed at the 30% rate; 2. you claim that the agreement reduces or adjusted taxes on income from non-independent personal services, retirement pensions, pension distributions, Social Security and other public pensions, or income from artists, athletes, students, trainees, teachers, etc. This does not include tax-free scholarships and grants; 3. you do not file a claim for a withholding tax on income under an international social security agreement or diplomatic or consular agreement; 4. you disclose information about a partnership or a trust or a beneficiary of a trust and a partnership, and if the agreement requires you to report information on the owner's U.S. trust, 5. you are not required to file a tax return as a foreign individual, which requires disclosure of the total amount of the beneficiary's financial assets in excess of $10,000 and does not relate to the payment of income from a foreign entity; 6. you are not required to file a tax return to the partner of a financial institution that is not a foreign entity, and does not have a foreign-based partnership; 6. you are not a taxable person who is not a beneficiary of a company that is not a tax-exempt to filed tax-exemptation partner (Section 1.38A, Section 542-S), 6.33 (No, Section 60), 6.6), and you are not a tax-exempt if you are not a tax-exempt if you are not a taxable person who is not a tax-exempt to a tax-exempt to a tax-exempt, you are not taxable, you are not taxable, you are not taxable, you are not taxable, you are not taxable, you are not taxable, you are not taxable) 6.

An international organization is an organization that is recognized as having tax-exempt status under the United States Tax Code, and is entitled to the privileges, exemptions, and exemptions provided by the International Organization Tax Exemption Act, and is designated by Executive Order of the President of the United States. The exemptions discussed in this chapter apply only to remuneration received for official services rendered to a foreign government or international organization. The income of a person who is eligible for these exemptions from other sources in the United States may be fully taxable or may be treated favourably under the relevant tax treaty clause. The proper treatment of this type of income (interest, dividends, etc.) has been addressed before this publication.

If there is a tax exemption clause in the Vienna Convention or bilateral consular agreement, you should check whether your salary qualifies for U.S. income tax exemption under this clause. If you are a U.S. citizen or resident, you are generally not eligible for income tax exemption under the Vienna Convention or bilateral consular agreement. For more information on the Vienna Convention and bilateral consular agreement, please email the Department of Consular Affairs' Office Abroad at OFMAssistants@state.gov.

Foreign government employees who are not eligible for any of the Vienna Convention, the Bilateral Consular Agreement, or any of the tax treaty exemption provisions may be exempt from U.S. income tax on their foreign government salaries if they meet the following requirements for exemption under U.S. tax law: The exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current foreign government employees and does not apply to former employees. Retirement pensions paid to former foreign government employees living in the United States are not eligible for the exemption discussed here.

Many treaties that establish international organizations include provisions that exempt your salary from U.S. income tax. If you are employed by an international organization in the United States, you should first check whether the international treaty that established the international organization for which you work has such a provision and whether you qualify for it. Generally, these provisions do not exempt U.S. citizens and resident employees from paying U.S. income tax.

If the international agreement that established the international organization for which you work does not include a tax exemption clause, and if you are not a U.S. citizen (or a U.S. citizen but also a Filipino national), you may be exempt from pay under U.S. tax law. For specific rules that may affect eligibility for this exemption, see "Expatriates who are maintaining an alien who is maintaining an immigrant status (legal permanent residence) " later. The exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of the international organization and does not apply to former employees.

If you sign a waiver as required by section 247 (b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (USCIS Form I-508) to maintain your legal permanent resident status (green card), you will no longer be eligible for tax exemption under U.S. tax law as of the date of filing the waiver. If you are an employee of a foreign government or international organization who is a permanent resident, you must be able to prove, in writing, that you have not signed and filed a USCIS Form I-508 and have received written proof from USCIS that you are eligible for tax exemption under U.S. tax law.

Before departing the United States, all aliens (except those on the list of aliens who do not require an exit or exit permit) must obtain a Compliance Certificate. This document is also called an exit or exit permit, and is part of the income tax form that must be filed before departure. You may obtain an exit or exit permit after you submit Form 1040-C or Form 2063. These forms are discussed in this section. If you need a permit to enter or exit the United States, please read the section entitled "Alien who does not require an exit or exit permit". If you do not fall into this discussion, you must obtain a permit to enter or exit the United States.

If you are a category (1) or (2) alien who has filed an exemption under section 247 (b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain an exit or exit permit, even if your income is exempt from U.S. taxation under an income tax treaty, consular treaty, or international treaty.

Foreign students who are entering the United States on an M-1 visa, or an M-2 visa, and whose spouse and children do not have income of U.S. origin during their stay in the United States on that visa, except for the following: income received from an employer approved by USCIS, or interest income on deposits not substantially connected with transactions or business in the United States (see Chapter 3 Interest Income).

If the alien earned taxable income and there is reasonable cause to believe that the alien's departure would jeopardize the collection of income tax, the IRS may require the alien to obtain an exit or exit permit. The following categories of aliens are exempt from the requirement for entry: 1. Foreign military trainees who entered the United States for training with the support of the Department of Defense and left the United States on an official military travel order; 2. Foreigners who do not reside in the United States or United States territory for more than 90 days for business purposes and who hold both a B-1 visa or B-1 and B-2 visas; 3. Non-resident tourists who are not in the United States or United States territory for more than 90 days; 4. Non-resident tourists who are in the United States as a C-1 visa or business visa and who are not traveling to or from the United States or United States territory via the border; 5. Non-resident tourists who do not have a passport, but do not have a visa, are exempt from entry into the United States.
If you are a resident of Canada or Mexico and you commute frequently between the United States and Canada and your salary is subject to U.S. withholding tax.

If you bring documents related to your income and stay in the United States to the TAC office, the issuance of departure or exit permits will proceed more quickly. If applicable, please bring the following records: 1. passport and alien registration card or visa. 2. a copy of the US income tax return filed for the last two years. If you have lived in the United States for less than two years, please bring the income tax return filed during that period. 3. income tax receipts paid for this return. 4. utility bills, expenses, receipts that can prove dependent family billed to the business, bank records, payment receipts, and other documents. 5. a copy of the income and withholding tax receipts paid by each employee from January 1 of the year in question until the day of departure.

If you must obtain an entry and exit permit, you must submit Form 2063 or Form 1040-C. Both forms have a Certificate of Compliance section. Once the certificate of compliance is signed by a representative of the local field support agent, it proves that the U.S. tax liability has been met based on the information that is valid. A copy of the signed Form 1040-C or a document that is detached from Form 2063 is your entry or exit permit.

For tax purposes, aliens who are not filing income tax returns or who fall into one of the categories of non-payers of income tax must file Form 2063 and pay income tax before they can be issued with an exit or exit permit. The exit or exit permit can be separated from Form 2063 and used for all exit dates during that year. However, if the IRS later believes that your exit may jeopardize your income tax, it may cancel your subsequent exit or exit permit.

If you are required to obtain an exit or exit permit and you are not eligible to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Generally, all income received or reasonably expected to be received during the tax year up to and including the date of departure must be reported on Form 1040-C and taxed thereon. If you have paid the taxes on Form 1040-C, filed all returns for the previous year, and paid all taxes due, you will receive an exit or exit permit. However, the IRS may authorize you to provide a bond to guarantee payment in lieu of paying certain taxes for the year.

If you provide information that the IRS will satisfy that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure will not prejudice the collection of tax, you may file Form 1040-C and obtain a departure or exit permit without paying the tax shown on this form. However, you must file all mandatory income tax returns that have not yet been filed and you must pay any income tax that is required to be paid on such returns. Your Form 1040-C must include all income that you earned or reasonably expect to earn during the entire year of your departure.

You must pay all tax liabilities that arose when you filed Form 1040-C, except for those that were secured or where the IRS is satisfied that your departure did not violate your income tax return. You must pay all of your past tax arrears. If you overpay on Form 1040-C, you will not have to pay any taxes when you file, but the IRS cannot provide a refund when you leave. If you have a refund, you must file Form 1040-NR at the end of the tax year.

Generally, you must pay your tax liability on the form at the time you file Form 1040-C, but if you paid all taxes due for the previous year and your Form 1040-C or tax return was not filed by the due date, you may instead pay your taxes on your tax return for the previous year by providing a tax-deferred bond that must be equal to the tax and interest calculated by the IRS by the due date. Information about the bond and the associated tax-deferred bond form can be obtained from the TAC office.

Form 1040-C is not an annual U.S. income tax return, so even if you have already filed Form 1040-C, you must file an income tax return if it is legally required. Chapters 5 and 7 discuss filing an annual U.S. income tax return. Taxes paid on Form 1040-C should be treated as a deduction for your entire year's tax liability on your annual U.S. income tax return.
If you have questions about your taxes, or need help with your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or guidelines, visit IRS.gov to find resources that can help you immediately.

After receiving all salary and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment benefit statements (in either postal or digital format), or other government payment statements (Forms 1099-G), interest, dividend, and retirement statements (Forms 1099), from banks and investment companies, you can choose from several options for completing and filing a tax return: prepare a tax return yourself, check to see if you meet the eligibility requirements for a free return preparation proxy, or hire a tax agent to complete the return.

Taxpayers who need information about the helpline counseling service can call 833-690-0598. The helpline counseling service can answer questions about current and future helpline items and services in alternative media formats (e.g., dot, large, audio, etc.). The helpline counseling service cannot access your IRS account. For tax, refund, or account-related matters, please visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp.

To complete a mobile-friendly form that requires a signature, you must have an IRS Online Account (OLA) or an IRS email address. You can submit the form online or download a copy and mail it to us. To certify your submission, you must scan the document. For more information, see IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms.

You can access information about your federal tax account securely at IRS.gov/Account. See your unpaid tax balances, sorted by year. See details of your payment plan or apply for a new payment plan. See your tax payments, your payment history for the last five years, and your current or scheduled payments. Access your tax records, including key data from your most recent tax return, your date of birth, and your age. See a digital copy of a select few IRS notices. Approve or reject an information approval request sent by a tax professional. Update your address or preferred method of contact.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information that can help you during tax season, including tax receipts, most recently filed tax returns, and adjusted gross income. Create an account at IRS.gov/Account or log into your online account.

The quickest and easiest way to get a tax refund is to file electronically and choose Direct Deposit to securely and electronically transfer your refund directly to your financial account. Direct deposit avoids the possibility of being transferred due to checks being lost, stolen, lost, or undelivered by the IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers use direct deposit to get their refund. If you don't have a bank account, visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit to find out more about where to find banks or credit unions to open an online account with.

Direct File is a free service for taxpayers in participating states who have a relatively simple tax return that reports certain types of income and applies for certain tax credits and deductions. Direct File does not file a state tax return, but if you live in a participating state, it provides you with a state government support tool that you can use to write and file a state tax return for free. See IRS.gov/DirectFile for more details, program updates, and frequently asked questions. Free File is a free program that provides free advice to taxpayers who do not have the ability to file a personal federal tax return directly with the IRS, but also offers free tax advisory services for taxpayers who have completed a free tax return. IRS offers free assistance to taxpayers who are not eligible to file a tax return online by visiting IRS.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov.gov.

The IRS does not first contact you via email, text message (including short links), telephone, or social media channels to verify or request your personal or financial information. This includes your personal identification number (PIN), a password or credit card number, and similar information related to your bank or other financial account. See IRS.gov/IdentityTheft for information on identity theft and data security for taxpayers, taxpayers, and businesses.

IRS Direct Pay: Pay individual tax returns or estimated taxes directly to a regular account or savings account for free. Direct debit card, credit card, or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor to pay taxes online or by phone. E-money: Schedule payments if you file federal tax returns through a tax return software or tax professional. Electronic federal tax return system: This is the best option for businesses. Registration required. Checks or Money Order: Payments are mailed to the address listed on the return or instruction.

If you're a sole proprietorship, partnership, or S corporation, you can access your tax information recorded with the IRS, and you can do more with your business account. See IRS.gov/BusinessAccount for more information.

The IRS uses these tools to share information with the public. Do not post SSNs or other confidential information on social media sites. Always protect your identity when using social networking sites. The following IRS YouTube channels offer short and useful videos on various tax-related topics in English, Spanish, and ASL: Youtube.com/irsvideosmultilingua (click in Chinese). Youtube.com/irsvideosmultilingua (click in Korean).

For income tax purposes, you must first determine whether you are a non-resident alien or a resident alien. If you were a non-resident and a resident in the same year, you have dual status. See dual-status aliens at the back. Also check the non-resident spouse you consider a resident and other special circumstances described at the back of this chapter.

If you were a lawful permanent resident of the United States at any time during the calendar year 2024, you are a resident for tax purposes. This is known as the green card test. If you have the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant at any time under the Immigration Act, you are a lawful permanent resident. If the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) (or its predecessor) issues you a Form I-551, also known as a green card, you generally have the status of a lawful permanent resident. You have the status of a permanent resident by this test, unless you have been deprived of your resident status or otherwise deemed to have given up this status administratively or legally.

If USCIS or the U.S. Consulate files a decision to revoke your resident status, your resident status will be considered abandoned when the final administrative order for surrender is issued. If an appeal to a federal court of competent jurisdiction is allowed, a final legal order is required. Legal permanent residents who are required to file a tax return as residents and fail to do so may be considered to have renounced their status, and legal permanent residents whose legal permanent residency has been suspended may be considered to have renounced their status and may be subject to special taxation requirements (see LTR 4 for the USCIS and the U.S. Consulate General).

The filing deadline is covered in Chapter 7. If you are required to file Form 8843 and you did not file Form 8843 on time, you cannot exclude days you were in the United States due to illness as a professional athlete or occurred while in the United States. This does not apply if you can show clear and conclusive evidence that you took reasonable steps to understand the filing requirements and to comply with those requirements.

It doesn't matter whether your permanent residence is a house, an apartment, or a furnished room, or whether you rented or owned a permanent residence, but it's important that your home is always available for continuous use and not just for short stays.

A dual resident taxpayer is a resident of the United States and another country, subject to the tax laws of each country.

If you meet the green card test at some point during the year but have not met the substantial stay test in that year, your residence start date is the first day of the current year that you have been in the United States as a lawful permanent resident. If you meet both the substantial stay test and the green card test, your residence start date is the earlier of the two days following the substantial stay test or the first day of the year that you reside in the United States as a lawful permanent resident.

If you choose to file jointly, you will usually make this choice. However, you may choose to do so by filing Form 1040-X, a revised U.S. personal income tax return. Attach Form 1040 or 1040-SR, and enter Amended at the top of the revised return. If you choose to use the revised tax return, you and your spouse must amend all tax returns you file after the year in which you made this choice.

If you are not required to file a tax return, you must file the return by the filing deadline of Form 1040-NR at the Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215. The filing deadline is covered in Chapter 7. If you have not filed the required return as described above, you cannot establish that you have close ties to a foreign country or foreign countries. This does not apply if you can show clear and convincing evidence that you have taken significant steps to comply with the filing requirements.

If you are a spouse of a U.S. citizen or permanent resident of the United States, and you are married and one of your spouses is a U.S. citizen or permanent resident and the other spouse is a nonresident alien, you may elect to treat your nonresident alien spouse as a U.S. resident. This includes the situation where one spouse is a nonresident alien at the beginning of the tax year, but is a resident alien at the end of the tax year, and the other spouse is a nonresident alien. If you make this choice, you and your spouse are considered resident for income tax purposes for the entire tax year.

If you have chosen this option on your amended tax return, you and your spouse must amend all tax returns you filed after the year you made your choice. Generally, you must file your amended joint tax return within three years of the date you filed your original U.S. income tax return, or no later than two years from the date you paid income tax in that year.

Once the choice is made, the choice to be considered a resident applies to all subsequent years unless it is deferred (as described in the later withdrawal of the choice) or terminated in the following manner: If the choice is terminated in one of the following ways, neither spouse may withdraw this choice on subsequent tax returns: 1. Withdrawal. If the choice is not terminated by the deadline for filing the tax return for the respective tax year, either spouse may withdraw this choice on all subsequent tax returns. The spouse who withdraws this choice must attach a signed statement declaring the choice of withdrawal.
After determining your residency status, you must determine the source of income. In this chapter, we will determine the source of income for the various types of income received on tax returns.

The income of a resident alien is generally taxed in the same manner as income of a U.S. citizen. A resident alien must report all interest, dividends, salaries and other services, rental or lease income, and other types of income on their U.S. tax return, including all income from sources within the United States and outside the United States.

Nonresident aliens are taxed only on income that is derived from within the United States and on certain income that is associated with transactions or business activities in the United States (see Chapter 4). However, the general rules for determining U.S. source income that apply to most nonresident aliens are set out in Table 2-1 below. The following discusses the general rules and the exceptions to these rules.

Real estate is property, land, buildings, and in general, everything that is built, cultivated, or attached to the land. Real estate in the United States includes all income, profits, and gains from the sale or other disposition of real property located in the United States.

Income from the sale of any farm, mine, dairy, gas station, etc., located in the United States and sold abroad, or any product from natural resources or timber, located in the United States, sold in the United States, is partly of U.S. origin. For information determining that part, see Regulation Section 1.863-1 (b).

Personal property is defined as any machine, equipment, or home that is not real property. If the taxpayer is resident in the United States, the gain or loss on the sale or exchange of the personal property is generally deemed to be sourced within the United States. If the taxpayer is not resident in the United States, the gain or loss on the sale or exchange of the personal property is generally deemed to be sourced outside the United States.

Inventory assets are private assets held primarily for sale to customers, either in stock or in the ordinary course of business. Income from the sale of purchased inventory assets is sourced from the place where the asset is sold. Generally, this is where ownership of the assets passes to the buyer. For example, income from the sale of inventory assets in the United States is U.S. sourced income, whether the inventory assets were purchased in the United States or abroad. Income from the sale of inventory assets produced in the United States and sold in other locations outside the United States (or vice versa) is sourced from the place where the assets were produced. This rule applies even if the tax residence is not in the United States.

The U.S. depreciation adjustment threshold is the allowable depreciation threshold for the basis of the asset as a whole when used to calculate the taxable income of the U.S. taxable person, but if the asset is used primarily in the U.S. during the period of taxation, the allowable depreciation threshold for the asset is the U.S. depreciation threshold or the U.S. depreciation threshold. However, it is used for certain transfers internationally, and there are some exceptions to the use of other assets. The depreciation threshold for the total depreciation threshold for the asset is based on the U.S. depreciation threshold, and if the depreciation threshold for the business is based on the depreciation threshold for the use of the asset, it is used to determine the amount of the asset that is available for sale to the public, as well as the amount of the cost of the asset, the capital loss incurred during the period of the transaction, and other costs that are normally allowable.

Intangible assets include patents, copyrights, proprietary rights, trademarks, mutual, or other similar assets. The sale of a tangible or intangible asset is taxed in the same way as the original tax. This is the same as the rules for taxing the sale of an intangible asset. For more information on how to apply the rules, see the rules for taxing the intangible asset. If the income from the sale is derived from the production, use, or disposal of the asset, the source of the income from the sale of the intangible asset is the country in which the asset was used.

Notwithstanding the foregoing, if you do not have a tax residence in the United States but maintain an office or other fixed place of business in the United States, the income from the sale of your personal property (including trust property) is treated as U.S. income attributable to your office or fixed place of business. However, if the office or other fixed place of business actually involved in the sale is located outside the United States, this rule does not apply to the sale of your inventory assets for use, disposal, or consumption in a location outside the United States. If you have a tax residence in the United States but maintain an office or other fixed place of business in a location outside the United States, the income from the sale of your inventory, depreciated assets, or personal property other than intangible assets, attributable to your office or fixed place of business in a location outside the United States, is treated as U.S. income. If less than 10% of the income from the sale is taxable in a foreign country, this income is treated as U.S. income. If the gain is derived from a foreign country, the rule also applies to the loss of income taxable in the United States.

The location and method of payment are not important in determining the source of income. In a securities lease or sale-repurchase transaction, the replacement interest paid to the stockholder is paid in the same manner as the interest on the embedded stock.

U.S. interest-bearing income does not include the following items: (1) interest paid is at least equal to 80% (0.80) of the total income of the payer for the three-year period ending with the expiration of the payer's interest-bearing taxable period, and (2) interest on bonds issued prior to August 10, 2010 and issued by a resident alien or a domestic corporation is not eligible if it is not of U.S. origin, (2) interest is not payable on bonds issued by a resident alien or a domestic corporation in a foreign country or territory, or (3) interest is not payable on bonds issued by a resident alien or a domestic corporation in a foreign country or territory, or (3) interest is not payable on bonds issued by a resident alien or a domestic corporation in a foreign country or territory, unless one of the following two conditions applies: (1) the recipient of such interest is a resident alien or has an interest in a domestic corporation; (2) the recipient of such interest is a resident alien or has an interest in a domestic corporation; (3) the term "debt" is not subject to the exclusion of the Exemption from the Exemption Act for the case of a debt was substantially changed after August 9, 2010; and (2) the term "debt" is not applicable to domestic debt that was paid by the resident alien or a foreign corporation; and (3) the domestic debt is payable by the foreign corporation is not payable to a domestic subsidiary of a domestic bank, domestic bank, a cooperative, a commercial bank, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, or an, a, a, a, a, or an, and b, and the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the, the,

In most cases, dividend income received from domestic corporations is U.S. sourced income, while dividend income from foreign corporations is usually foreign sourced income. The exception to the second rule, discussed later, is that the alternative dividend paid to the stockholder in a securities lease or exchange-traded fund transaction is sourced in the same way as the dividend on the embedded stock.

As with the top distributor who sponsors the sub-distributor, certain companies selling products through multi-level marketing agreements are entitled to receive money based on the specific activities of the sub-distributor. Generally, depending on the facts, these multi-level marketing companies consider the money received from the sale or purchase of the sponsored person (s) to the independent (non-employee) distributor (s) (top distributor) as income for the performance of personal services that recruit, educate and support the sub-distributor. The source of income is usually based on the area of the top distributor's service, and may be considered to be a multi-year remuneration, depending on the fact, and the source of income is determined by the period in which the guarantee is granted.

If you are self-employed, you will determine the source of compensation for work or personal services that you perform for your self-employment using the criteria that most accurately reflect the appropriate source of income, depending on the facts and circumstances of your particular case. In most cases, a time-based allocation is required depending on the facts and circumstances, as described below.

The source of the multi-year benefit is generally determined by the period over which the benefit was earned, usually on a time basis. A multi-year benefit is a benefit that is included in your income for one tax year but is earned for a period that includes more than two tax years. Depending on the facts and circumstances, the amount of the benefit that is specifically associated with a period that includes multiple tax years is determined by the totality of the multi-year period. For example, the amount of the benefit that is specifically associated with a period that includes multiple tax years is determined by multiplying the total multi-year benefit by the fraction of the total multi-year benefit.

If you are an employee, you may determine the source of compensation based on alternative criteria if you can satisfactorily establish to the IRS that the source of your salary is more appropriate than the time or geographic basis depending on the facts and circumstances. If you use an alternative criterion, you must keep documented (and searchable) records explaining why the alternative criterion is more appropriate for determining your source of income. Also, if all of your salary from all sources is $250,000 or more, check "Yes" on both questions of Line K of Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR) and attach to your tax return a statement that contains all of the following in writing: 1. your name and SSN (written at the top of the statement). 2. the specific income or specific retirement income for which you intend to use the alternative criterion. 3. for each item, the source of the alternative criterion used. 4. for each item of the alternative criterion that the alternative criterion will replace, the method by which the salary is determined. 5. for each item, the method by which the alternative criterion is determined.

The term "cargo" or "cargo" includes containers used in connection with the ship or aircraft. Income from all carriage that begins or ends in the United States is considered to have originated in the United States. If the carriage begins or ends in the United States, 50% of the income from the carriage is considered to have originated in the United States. If the carriage was between the United States and a U.S. territory, 50% of the income from the carriage from personal services is U.S. source income. For non-resident aliens, only income that originated on an aircraft or related to it is considered to be taxable. For more information on how income from carriage is taxed in the U.S., see Section 4 of the Income Tax Act of 1936, which amended the U.S. Tax Code of 1936, as amended by the U.S. Tax Code of 1936, as amended by the U.S. Tax Code of 1936, as amended by the U.S. Tax Code of 1936, and as amended by the U.S. Tax Code of 1936, as amended by the U. Tax Code of 1936, as amended by the U. Tax Code of 1936, and as amended by the U. Tax Code of 1936, as amended by the U.

Generally, the source of a scholarship, research grant, grant, award, or prize is the recipient's place of residence, regardless of whether or not the grant was actually funded. However, note that subsequent activities conducted outside the United States, such as funds paid to the U.S. government, an illegal U.S. resident, or a domestic corporation for research or education in the United States, are U.S. funds. If a foreign government or foreign corporation receives a similar payment, the money is foreign, even if it is passed through a U.S. agent. Funds paid by an entity designated as an international public agency under the International Organization for Migration Exemption Act are foreign funds.

Scholarships, research grants, targeted grants, and awards for activities performed outside the United States by nonresident aliens are not U.S. source income. This rule does not apply to amounts received in compensation for services, such as salaries. For applicable source rules, see the previous section on individual services.

If you receive a pension from a domestic trust for services performed both in the United States and abroad, part of this pension is of U.S. origin. The other part is the amount attributed to the income of the pension plan and the employer's contribution for services performed in the United States. This applies regardless of whether the withdrawal was paid from a qualifying or non-qualifying stock bonus, pension, profit sharing or fixed payment plan (whether funded or unfunded). If you have served as an employee of the U.S. government, you may receive a dividend from the U.S. government, such as the Civil Service Retirement System, which is considered a qualifying pension plan. Your U.S. income is the taxable total amount of the dividend that is included in your gross U.S. government base income (not the tax-exempt portion of the service performed in the U.S. territory).

If you must file a U.S. federal income tax return, you may qualify for some of the special disaster-related rules related to the use of retirement funds. For more information, see Publication 590-B. Also visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

Your U.S. source income includes rental and royalty income received at the applicable tax rate for assets or interests in assets located in the United States. U.S. source income also includes fees or royalties for the privilege of or use of intangible assets owned or held in the United States, such as patents, copyrights, proprietary procedures and manufacturing laws, sales, trademarks, franchises and similar assets.
In these cases, you and your spouse must report your joint income, which will be explained later.

Except for a partner's share of income from transactions or business or partnership income, no income from a spouse's employment is treated as income from a spouse whose service generated the income. This spouse must report all of it on his or her individual return.

Transactional or business income, not a partner's share of the partnership income, is treated as income from a spouse's transactional or business activities, which the spouse must report on their individual return.
The partner's share of the partnership income (or loss) is treated as the partner's income (or loss). This partner must report all of it on their individual return.

Individual property income from one spouse (not income from employment, transactions or business, or partnership dividends) is treated as income of that spouse. This spouse must report all of it on his or her individual return. Use the appropriate couple's joint property laws to determine what separate property is.
All other joint income is treated by the applicable joint property laws.

Resident and nonresident aliens are allowed exclusions from gross income if they meet certain conditions. Exclusions from gross income are income that is not generally included in the U.S. income you earn and is not subject to U.S. taxation. This chapter covers the more general exclusions allowed to resident and nonresident aliens.
Resident foreigners can exclude the following items from their total income.

If you are staying in a foreign country or several foreign countries for at least 330 days in any consecutive 12-month period, you may be eligible for the foreign worker income exclusion. The amount of the 2024 exclusion is $126,500. Additionally, certain foreign accommodation amounts may be excluded or deducted. You may also be eligible if you are a resident of a foreign country and a citizen or national of a country that has an income tax treaty with the United States.
Non-resident foreigners may exclude the following items from their gross income:

It shall be the purpose of this chapter to authorize such persons and businesses as may be necessary to carry on their business in the United States, to accomplish and perform such duties and to preserve the benefits of such persons and businesses, to extend to such persons and businesses the benefits of such persons and businesses, and to provide for such persons and businesses the means by which such persons and businesses may obtain such benefits.

Interest on debt of a state or a federal district, the District of Columbia, or a U.S. territory is generally not included in income, but interest on certain private business bonds, interest-only bonds, and certain bonds that are not in registered form are included in income.

Interest on eligible portfolio interest and OIDs are not subject to Chapter 3 withholding tax under sections 1441 to 1443, but interest is a withholding payment and interest may be withheld on the relevant portfolio interest if there is no exception to Chapter 4 withholding tax under sections 1471 to 1474. For more information, see the discussion on portfolio interest on certain income under withholding tax in Publication 515 (in English). To be eligible for portfolio interest, interest must have been paid on bonds issued after July 18, 1984, otherwise withholding tax will apply. For bonds issued after March 18, 2012, this does not include portfolio holders who paid for bonds without a registered bond.

Conversely, if a bond that was considered to be in a registered form is changed to a non-form bond at any time in the future, it is not considered to have been in a registered form at that particular time. For more information on whether a bond is considered to be in a registered form, see the discussion on portfolio interest under the specific income tax provision in Publication 515 (English).

You are not required to file for interest on a perpetual bond to qualify for portfolio interest relief, but, in some cases, you may need to file for the purposes of Form 1099 for the reporting of a withdrawal and for the provisional withdrawal.

Payments to individuals and payments of conditional interest are not eligible as portfolio interest, and you must collect the statutory interest on such payments at source, unless there are other exceptions, such as the provisions of the agreement that must be applied.

The following are among the conditional interest: 1. interest determined by the following criteria: the amount received, sold, or cash flows of the creditor or related person, the income or earnings of the creditor or related person, changes in the value of the assets of the creditor or related person, or dividends, partnership distributions, or similar payments paid by the creditor or related person. See section 871 (h) (iv) (iv) (iv) (c) for exceptions.
The dividend income below is exempt from 30% tax.

There's no 30% tax on any interest-related dividend received in the U.S. from a mutual fund or other regulated investment company, and the mutual fund will specify in writing which dividend is an interest-related dividend.

Certain short-term capital gains dividends received from a mutual fund or other RIC originating in the United States may not be taxed at 30%. The mutual fund specifies in writing which dividends are short-term capital gains dividends. This tax relief does not apply if you have stayed in the United States for more than 183 days during the taxable period.

If you do not meet all three conditions, then the income you receive from the performance of a personal service in the United States is income of United States origin and is taxable under the rules in Chapter IV. If your salary for these services is $3,000 or more, the total amount is income from transactions or business in the United States. To determine whether your salary is more than $3,000, we require an explanation of the amount of the advance or change received from your employer, and if so, we do not include the cost. If the advance or change is more than your cost, we recommend that you include the excess in your salary for these services. We recommend that you include the excess in your salary for the service. We recommend that you include the excess in your salary for the service, as a day in any period of time that is substantially restricted by the United States.

Remuneration for services performed in the United States as a nonresident alien in connection with the temporary detention of an individual as a regular seaman of a foreign vessel (e.g., a boat or ship) that has carried cargo between the United States and a foreign country or U.S. territory is not income of U.S. origin and is not exempt from U.S. taxation. Exceptions to this do not apply to salaries for services performed in a foreign aircraft.

Nonresident foreign students and exchange visitors who are in the United States on an F, J, M, N, or Q visa may be excluded from gross earnings received from a foreign employer. This group includes actual students, academics, trainees, teachers, professors, research assistants, professionals, or those of a similar category who are leaders or leaders in a field of professional knowledge or technology. The spouse and minor children of the foreign national who accompanied or subsequently accompanied the foreign national in question are also included. Nonresident foreigners are temporarily in the United States on a J-1 visa and include foreign individuals who are entering the United States as exchange visitors under the 1961 Mutual Educational and Cultural Exchange Act.
The term, "foreign employer" does not include foreign governments, but the income received from foreign governments is exempt from U.S. income tax, as discussed in Chapter 10.

All types of income that are exempt from U.S. tax under an agreement to which the United States is a party are excluded from the taxpayer's gross income, but income subject to taxation that is limited by the agreement is included in gross income. See Chapter 9.

The winnings from legal gambling on horse and dog racing live in the United States, betting on horse and dog racing in the United States, and betting on betting on horse racing outside the United States are excluded from your gross income.

If you are a degree applicant, you may exclude some or all of the amount received as a qualifying scholarship from your income. The rules discussed here apply to both resident and nonresident aliens. If a nonresident alien received a grant from a non-U.S. source, U.S. tax is not applicable. Please refer to the scholarship, grant, award, and fellowship award in Chapter 2 to determine whether you received a grant from a U.S. source. Scholarships or study fees are excluded from your income only if: 1. you are a degree applicant at a qualifying educational institution, and 2. you used the grant and research funds to pay for qualifying education expenses.

Any part of a scholarship, grant, or tuition deduction received in exchange for past, present, or future educational research or other services cannot be excluded from income, even if all degree candidates are required to perform these services as a condition of receiving a degree.

Are resident aliens and nonresident aliens taxed differently? Are resident aliens generally taxed the same as U.S. citizens? Are nonresident aliens taxed based on the source of income and whether the income is substantially related to a transaction or business in the United States? The discussion below will help the taxpayer determine whether the income you received is substantially connected to a transaction or business in the United States and how it is taxed.

Non-resident aliens are generally taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens, which means that worldwide income is subject to U.S. taxation and must be reported on a U.S. tax return. Non-resident aliens' income is subject to the withholding tax rate applicable to U.S. citizens. Non-resident aliens use the tax slips and tax calculation worksheets that apply to U.S. citizens, which are included in the instructions for Form 1040.

The difference between these two categories is that substantially connected income is taxed at the unearned tax rate after allowable deductions, which is the rate applicable to U.S. citizens and resident aliens alike. Virtually unconnected income is taxed at a flat rate of 30% (or the lower agreed tax rate). If you were previously a U.S. citizen, or resident alien, this rule does not apply.

In general, for your income received in the year to be considered substantially connected with your business or trade, you must have engaged in business or trade in the taxable year in question. Whether you engaged in business or trade in the United States depends on the characteristics of your activity. The following discussion will help you determine whether you engaged in business or trade in the United States.

If you are a resident of the United States and you perform personal services for tax purposes at any time, you are considered to be engaged in a transaction or business within the United States. Certain benefits paid by a foreign employer to a nonresident alien are not included in gross income. For more details, see Working for a foreign employer in Chapter 3.

If you are temporarily in the United States on a nonimmigrant status F, J, M, Q, or Q visa and are not engaged in a trade or business, you are considered to be engaged in a trade or business in the United States if you participated in the scholarship or research grant program described in section 1441 (b) and had a taxable income. The taxable portion of the scholarship or grant of a U.S. source is treated as substantially connected with the trade or business in the United States.

If your sole U.S. business activity is trading in stocks, securities, or commodities through a U.S. resident broker or agent (including hedge transactions), you are not engaged in trading or business in the United States. For stocks, securities, and commodities, this also applies to nonresident aliens, including stock and securities dealers or brokers. For commodities, this also applies to commodities that are traded on organized commodity exchanges and to transactions that occur on such exchanges. If you have an office or other fixed place of business in the United States or have traded in stocks, securities, or commodities under the direction of such broker or agent, then the discussion is not applicable.

That if you are a dealer and you have traded stocks, securities, or commodities through your account, that does not mean that you are a dealer and that you are deemed to have engaged in trading or business in the United States. That is determined on a case-by-case basis or by the facts and circumstances as set forth in the rules given in the above section on trading stocks, securities, or commodities.

If you are engaged in a transaction or business in the United States, then you treat all income, gains, and losses (other than specific investment income) of U.S. origin in that tax year as substantially connected income. This applies regardless of whether the income is related to the transaction or business conducted in the United States. The two tests described later in Investment Income determine whether you treat certain items of investment income (such as interest, dividends, and royalties) as having a substantial connection to the business in question.

Use the two tests described below to determine whether any U.S.-sourced income item in the above three categories received in the taxable year has a material connection to a U.S. trade or business. If the test indicates that the income item has a material connection, you must include it with other material connected income. If the income item is not material connected, include it with all other income discussed in the 30% tax at the end of this chapter.
So, this test assumes that if the performance of a trade or business in the United States was the primary factor in generating income, that income was substantially involved.

When you exercise personal services in the United States, you are generally engaged in a transaction or business in the United States.The personal services income received by you from engaging in a transaction or business in the United States is substantially connected with that transaction or business in the United States for tax purposes.If it can be substantially connected with the income received for reasons that were in the year you exercised the service, it is also substantially connected with the income received for reasons that were not in the year you exercised the service.Personal services income includes salary, annuities, commissions, fees, expenses, and employee benefits and bonuses.This income may be paid to you in the form of cash, services, or assets.

If you were employed in the United States after 1986 and subsequently received a pension or retirement benefit distribution attributable to that service as a nonresident alien in the taxable year, such distribution is linked to income only to the extent that you actually contributed, regardless of whether you were engaged in a trade or business in the United States in the year in which you received the pension or retirement benefit distribution.

A fixed place of business refers to a place, location, structure, or similar facility that is generally used to transact or conduct business. A fixed-term scheduled carrier means a ship or aircraft that makes a regular periodic and repeated voyage or passage to or from the United States on a publicly announced schedule. This definition applies to both scheduled and charter air transportation. If the above two conditions are not met, the income is effectively unconnected and is taxed at a rate of 4%.

that all profits of U.S. origin derived from the operation of a business in the United States are substantially connected with the transaction or business in the United States. For example, that the proceeds of the sale in the United States of inventory assets purchased in the United States or abroad are substantially connected with the transaction or business income. That the portion of the profits of a partnership engaged in a transaction or business in the United States is also substantially connected with the transaction or business in the United States.
