All gains and losses (whether capital assets or capital assets) arising from the sale or exchange of any interest in real estate in the United States are taxed in the same manner as if you were engaged in any transaction or business in the United States. You must treat the gains and losses as materially connected with the transaction or business.

It means a portion of a property located in the United States or the U.S. Virgin Islands, or a portion of a domestic corporation that is a U.S. real estate holding company (other than a debtor). Real property includes: 1. land and crops from land not separated from it, such as growing grains, timber, and minerals, etc. 2. natural resources that are deposited, such as buildings, other permanent structures, and their structural elements, etc. 3. land development; 3. property, other than those listed below, which is used for housing, or the use of rental office space; 4. personal property that is disposed of one year before or one year after the disposal of the property; 5. personal property sold separately to a person not related to the seller or buyer of the property; 6. real property.
If you dispose of a U.S. real estate interest, you may be required to withhold tax on the sale of your home. See the discussion on withholding tax on the sale of real estate in Chapter 8.
Unless the entity is a U.S. real estate holding company, all shares of the domestic entity are treated as shares of the U.S. real estate holding company.

Unless you own more than 5% of the fair market value of the class of shares in question (or more than 10% of the shares in the case of a real estate investment trust (REIT)), a U.S. real estate holding does not include the class of shares of a company that is regularly traded on an established stock exchange. Unless the company has chosen to be treated as a domestic company, a foreign company holding U.S. real estate is generally not a U.S. real estate holding.

A QIE is a REIT or RIC that is treated as a U.S. real estate holding corporation (after the application of certain rules to Section 897 (h) (iv) (A) (ii). For more detailed information, see Publication 515 (English) of the U.S. Real Estate Division.

In most cases, distributions paid to a QIE due to gains derived from the sale or exchange of a nonresident alien, foreign corporation, or QIE's U.S. real estate interest are treated as gains recognized by the QIE from the sale or exchange of that nonresident alien, foreign corporation, or U.S. real estate interest. Certain exceptions apply to the transparency rules for distributions by QIE. If a shareholder owns less than 5% of the stock at any time during the year ending on the date of the distribution (or less than 10% of the stock in the case of a REIT) of the QIE's dividend on the stock that is regularly traded on the U.S. stock market, that dividend is not treated as a sale or exchange gain of the U.S. real estate interest.

Disposals of REIT stock held directly by the qualifying shareholder (or indirectly through one or more partnerships) are not treated as U.S. real estate holdings. For more information, see Sections 897 (k) (2) through (4).

If such circumstances arise, the gain is treated as having been made to you through the sale or exchange of a U.S. real estate interest in an amount equal to the amount that should have been treated as a gain. This also applies to the replacement dividend payment. It is not treated as a Warranty Third Applicable Transaction if you have actually received a dividend from a QIE regulated in the country in which the transaction was made through the disposal or acquisition of such interest. It is only if you have not held more than 5% of the shares of this class at any time during the one-year period from the date of the distribution that you have disposed of any type of shares of QIE regularly traded on the existing U.S. stock market.
The net income from the disposal of your U.S. real estate holdings may be subject to a minimum tax, and if there is a tax, calculate the amount on Form 6251.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner of a U.S. or foreign partnership engaged in (or treated as engaged in) a transaction or business in the United States, and if you directly or indirectly dispose of the interest therein, the gain or loss on the disposition of the partnership interest may affect federal taxation. Pursuant to section 864 (c) (c) (8) the gain or loss arising from the sale, exchange or other disposal of the partnership interest shall be deemed to be materially related to the activities of the partnership interest in the United States (whether the gain or loss is materially connected to the transaction or business). However, the amount of the provision for materially connected gain or loss shall be limited to a portion of the distribution of the profit or loss on the disposition of the interest that would have arisen if the partnership had disposed of all of its assets at fair market value on a day-to-day basis.

Income of foreign origin that is equivalent to the items of income described above is treated as substantially connected to a transaction or business in the United States. For example, if this income is income earned by a foreign national in the United States through banking, finance, or similar types of business, the foreign-source interest and dividend equivalent payments are treated as substantially connected to income in the United States.

The income you derive from a transaction or business in the United States that is substantially connected with the taxable year in which the transaction or business was made is taxable at the rate applicable to U.S. citizens or residents after the allowable deduction. Generally, only nonresident aliens engaged in a transaction or business in the United States may receive the income substantially connected with the taxable year in which the transaction or business was made. However, the consideration received for the sale or exchange of property, provision of services, or other transaction in the taxable year in which the transaction or business was made, if such consideration could be treated as income substantially connected with the taxable year in which the transaction or business was made, is treated as income substantially connected with the taxable year in which the payment was received.
You can choose to treat all real estate income as essentially connected.
The 30% (or lower agreed) rate of taxation applies only to income or gains of U.S. origin on certain items that are not substantially connected with a U.S. transaction or business.

If paid intermittently, the income may be periodic. This does not mean that it must be paid annually or over a fixed period of time. It may be either annually or periodically, even if the period over which the payment occurs increases or decreases. Items included in a particular fixed or determinable income may include interest (other than OID), dividends, allowances equal to dividends (as defined in Section 2), rent, insurance premiums, annuities, salaries, other remuneration, and any securities received through a loan or exchange deal.

Unless the income is substantially linked to a U.S. transaction or business and is excluded by the treaty, in general, nonresident aliens are taxed at 30% on the gross gambling winnings earned in the United States. However, gambling income earned by nonresident aliens in the United States from winning at blackjack, baccarat, craps, roulette, or Big Six Wheel is not taxed. Nonresident aliens are taxed at a different rate on the net gambling income earned in the United States that is substantially connected to a U.S. transaction or business. This income is exempt under some tax treaties. See Table 1 of the Tax Agreements at IRS.gov/TreatyTables. For more information, see Publication 915 of the United States Tax Code.

Nonresident aliens must include 85% of their US Social Security benefits (and the Social Security equivalent of the first-class railroad retirement benefit portion) as US-sourced FDAP income. Social Security benefits include monthly retirement, survivor, and disability benefits. This income is excluded under some tax treaties. For a list of tax treaties that exclude the Social Security withholding from US taxes, see the Tax Treaty Tables provided at IRS.gov/TreatyTables. For more information, see Publication 915 (in English).

If you choose to treat the gain in question as substantially connected with a U.S. transaction or business, the gain in (1) above is exempt from the 30% (or lower) tax rate. See Real Estate Income below.

If you have not engaged in a transaction or business in the United States and have not established a taxable income for the previous period, then for purposes of the 183-day rule, your taxable income will be the prior year. You must also file a tax return based on the prior year. If you have stayed in the United States for less than 183 days in the relevant taxable year, then capital gains (other than those listed below) are tax-exempt, provided that your taxable income is not substantially linked to the transaction or business in the United States.

If you are a resident of the United States and you are not physically connected with a transaction or business in the United States, report all gains and losses on the sale and exchange of capital assets (including real estate) on Schedule D (Form 1040), Form 4797, or both, attached to Form 1040-NR.

You may elect to treat all income from the source of such property as being substantially connected with a transaction or business in the United States, and all income from the source of such property as is located in the United States and held for the purpose of creating an income, and all income for the ownership of such property, including income for rent, royalties from coal mines, gas, and other natural resources, and income from the sale or exchange of timber, petroleum, coal, or domestic iron ore, with a vested economic interest. You may make this election only in respect of income from real property that was not substantially connected with a transaction or business in the United States. Upon such election, you may be charged a contribution due on the income from the property, and only income from the real property will be taxed. In such case, you may elect to treat as a nonresident alien who did not transact or do business in the United States, or as a resident alien who did not transact or do business in the United States, and you may be deemed to have entered into a taxable partnership with the United States.

All of your U.S.-origin transportation income is subject to the 4% tax rate applicable to all U.S.-origin transportation income, including only transportation income that is treated as originating from a U.S. source where the transportation begins and ends in the U.S. For transportation income for personal services, it must be transportation between the U.S. and U.S. territories; for personal services of non-resident aliens, it applies only to income derived from or related to aircraft.

Under this rule, unless a higher tax is applied to you by Section 871 (the rules normally applicable to taxation of income of nonresident aliens discussed below) after taking into account all applicable treaty benefits, the gross net income and gains of the United States of America during the period in which you were a nonresident are taxed at the rate of the excess tax due to the individual (after allowable deductions). For more information on how to calculate the special tax, see the section on national withholding tax at the back.

If you have already filed a tax return for this period, you must file an amended return. You must attach a statement to your tax return that states the source of all your gross U.S. and foreign income and the income items to which this special rule applies.

If you have been a lawful permanent resident of the United States for eight or more of the 15 years since the tax year in which you ended your residence, you are an LTR. When determining whether you meet the eight-year requirement, the years in which you were not considered a resident of a foreign country by the tax treaty and did not renounce the benefits of the treaty are not counted.

If you are not a national renunciant in the year you renounce U.S. citizenship or end long-term residency, you must first file Form 8854. Additionally, you must file Form 8854 annually if you have been a national renunciant since renouncing citizenship or if you are one of the following: 1. late payment of appraisal tax (see late payment of appraisal tax in the back row). 2. have an eligible late payment item, or 3. have a contribution to a non-donor trust.

You are considered to have renounced U.S. citizenship on the earliest of the following dates: 1. the date on which you renounced U.S. citizenship at a U.S. Embassy or Consulate (if confirmed by the issuance of a Certificate of Loss of Nationality after voluntary renunciation); 2. the date on which you submitted a signed U.S. Citizenship self-denial form to the Department of State confirming the enforcement of a citizenship renunciation action (if confirmed by the issuance of a Certificate of Loss of Nationality after voluntary renunciation); 3. the date on which the Department of State issued a Certificate of Loss of Nationality; 4. the date on which your naturalization certificate was revoked by a U.S. court.

You have renounced your permanent residence in the United States on the earliest of the following dates: 1. the date you voluntarily renounced your legal status as a permanent resident by submitting a Homeland Security Form I-407 to a U.S. Consulate or Immigration Office; 2. the date on which you renounced your legal status as a permanent resident (or, if you have appealed against such action, the date on which the last court order related to such administrative action was issued); 3. the date on which the last administrative order for deportation from the United States under the Immigration and Nationality Act was issued; 4. if you were a dual resident of a country with which the United States has entered into an income tax treaty, you notified the IRS for processing on Forms 8833 and 8854 and you are considered to be a permanent resident of this country under the terms of the treaty; see the effective date of the treaty in section 1 for more information on dual resident aliens.

If you renounce your citizenship after June 16, 2008, you are considered to have renounced your citizenship and the rules for renouncing citizenship apply to you under Section 877A if you meet one of the following conditions: (1) if you renounced your citizenship or residency in 2024, (2) if your average annual net income for the five-year period ending before the date of renouncing citizenship or residency is more than $201,000, (3) if your net worth on the date of renouncing citizenship or residency is more than $2 million, and (4) if you have not provided proof of compliance with U.S. federal tax obligations for five years from the date of renouncing citizenship or residency on Form 8854.

Income tax on unrealized net gains (or losses) on the sale of assets at fair market value (the "Chesy assessment") the day before the date of renunciation of citizenship applies to the year in which you renounced citizenship. This applies to most types of asset holdings held on the date of renunciation of citizenship or the date of termination of residency. However, please note exceptions thereafter. Gains from considered sales must be considered in the year in which the considered sale occurred, regardless of other U.S. tax laws. Losses from considered sales must be considered within the limits specified in the U.S. tax laws, but not in Section 1091 (non-allowance for loss on the Washiell sale of stocks and bonds). If you renounced citizenship or terminated residency in 2024, you must deduct $866,000 from your net income, which must be included in your income, unless otherwise specified (at least $0.00).

However, items (1) and (3) are subject to withholding tax at the source. For items (2), you are deemed to have received the accrued benefit at its present value on the date of your national surrender. For items (4), you are deemed to have received a distribution for the total interest in the account one day prior to the date of your national surrender. For more information, please refer to the instructions and notices on Form 8854 and Notice 2009-85.

Once you have determined your alien status, the source of income, and whether and how your income is taxed in the United States, the next step is tax calculation. The information for resident aliens in this chapter is not as comprehensive as the information for nonresident aliens. Because the information on filing a tax return for resident aliens is generally the same as for U.S. citizens, resident aliens should receive publications, forms, and explanations for U.S. citizens. If you are both a resident alien and a resident alien on a single tax return, please refer to the section discussing dual-identity aliens in Chapter 6.

Nonresident aliens may claim a portion of the itemized deductions that resident aliens may claim. However, nonresident aliens may only claim the itemized deductions if their income is substantially linked to a transaction or business in the United States. There may be a limit to the total amount of the itemized deductions that may be claimed on Schedule A. Please refer to the instructions on Schedule A (Form 1040) or the instructions on Form 1040-NR (in English) for the itemized deductions on Schedule A (Form 1040-NR).

You may deduct certain item-by-item expenses if you receive income that is materially connected with a transaction or business in the United States. You may generally only include appropriately allocated and allocated expenses and losses on income that is materially connected with a U.S. transaction or business. You may not include expenses and/or losses related to exempt income or income that is materially connected with a U.S. transaction or business.

Special rules apply to students and corporate trainees who are eligible for the benefits of Section 21 (b) (2) of the American Indian Income Tax Act. If you have not charged an itemized fee, you may charge a standard fee. Use worksheet 5-1 to calculate the standard fee for 2024. If you are married and your spouse filed a return and chose the itemized fee, you may not choose the standard fee.

If you are a student and corporate trainee who qualifies under Section 21 (2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Agreement (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/Disasters) for a disaster that the federal government has declared to have affected you in 2024, you may be able to choose to increase the standard deduction by as much as the qualifying disaster-related personal injury loss on your 2024 tax return. Use Task 5-1 to calculate the standard deduction for 2024, see Form 4684 of 2024, and for more information on the tax benefits for qualifying disaster-related personal injury losses in the guidance.

State and local income taxes paid on income substantially connected with a transaction or business in the United States may be deducted. The total deduction is limited to a total of $10,000 (or $5,000 for individual filings by departments). If you received a refund or rebate of taxes paid in the previous year in 2024, do not deduct the deduction by the amount. If you deducted taxes in the previous year and the deduction reduced your tax, you must include the refund and rebate in your income.

Direct donations to foreign entities are not eligible. However, donations to U.S. entities that transfer funds to charitable organizations abroad are eligible if the U.S. entity controls the flow of funds or if the foreign entity is an administrative branch of the U.S. entity. Under a limited number of income tax treaties, you may be eligible to make a donation to a charitable organization abroad.

If your loss is due to a disaster declared by the federal government, you may deduct the loss even if your assets were not associated with a transaction or business in the United States. These assets may be personal use assets or income-generating assets that are not associated with transactions or businesses in the United States. The assets must be located in the United States at the time of the disaster or theft. You may deduct the loss only in the year in which the loss was discovered. Use Form 4684 and its instructions to calculate the deductible loss and the loss of the theft. For more information, see Publication 547".
Resident aliens use the same rules as U.S. citizens to report tax credits and tax payments, including withholding tax. The items below are some of the tax credits you may claim.

You may claim a deduction for income taxes paid and incurred on income from a foreign country or from a foreign source, within certain limits. You may not claim a deduction for taxes paid or incurred on income from a foreign worker who is excluded. If you claim a deduction for income taxes paid or incurred in a foreign country, you must generally file Form 1116 along with Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

If you are a parent of a qualifying child under 13 years of age or a dependent parent with a disability, or you have paid someone to care for a spouse with a disability, and the reason for this was that you were working or looking for a job, you can claim this tax credit. For more information, see Form 2441 and Publication 503.

If you are 65 years of age or older or have retired with permanent or complete disability, you may be eligible for this tax deduction. For more information on this tax deduction, see Publication 524 and Schedule R (Form 1040).

If you have paid the qualifying tuition fees for yourself, your spouse, or dependents, you may be eligible for the deduction. There are two types of education deductions: the American Opportunity Tax Deduction and the Lifetime Education Tax Deduction.

The other dependent family tax credit is for those with dependent families who are unable to apply for the child tax credit. Eligible dependent families must be U.S. citizens, U.S. nationals, or U.S. resident aliens, and must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued prior to the 2024 filing deadline (including the extension).

EICs may reduce the amount of tax payable and provide refunds. For more information, visit IRS.gov/EIC. If you (and your spouse) have a child with a SSN issued before the 2024 filing deadline, including joint filing, you (and your spouse) are not eligible to claim the SSN as a new card issued after the original 2024 tax filing deadline or a revised source of income tax return. If your child has a valid Social Security card issued after the 2024 filing deadline or a revised source of income tax return, and the child does not have a Social Security card issued after the 2024 filing deadline or a revised source of income tax return, and the child is not eligible to write a social security card for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for the SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSN for SSE for SSN for SSN for SSE
You can claim a portion of the same tax deduction as a resident alien can claim for certain taxes that have been paid, or are believed to have been paid, or are recovered from your income.
You can only claim a tax credit if you actually receive a connected income, and you can claim some of the following tax credits.

If you are a resident of the United States and you have foreign-source income substantially connected with a transaction or business in the United States, you may claim a tax credit for income taxes paid or incurred on that income in the United States or in foreign countries. If you are a foreign national, you may not claim a tax credit for income taxes paid or incurred in the United States or in foreign countries, or for income taxes only due to your status as a foreign national or resident of a U.S. territory, and you may not receive any credit for taxes imposed on U.S.-source income in those countries or in U.S. territories. If you claim a foreign-source income tax credit, you must generally attach Form 1116 to your tax return. For more information, see Publication 514 (English).

A married nonresident alien may claim this tax credit if they choose to file jointly with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse, as outlined in the Choice 1 method, or if they qualify as a married individual who does not live with them (see Joint Filing Test in Publication 503 (see Joint Filing Test in Publication 503 (see 503 in the U.S. Code)). The total cost of caring for a child and dependent who is eligible for a tax credit on all taxable income is not greater than the income earned in the U.S. by the person for whom the tax credit is paid. Such income generally means a salary, and for more information on personal services, see Publication 503 (see 503 in the U.S. Code)).

If you have an adopted child, you are always considered a child of your own. Adopted children include children who have been legally placed for legal adoption. If you do not have an SSN or ITIN issued on or before the 2024 filing deadline (including extension deadlines), you cannot claim a child tax credit on your original 2024 tax return or amended tax return. If your child does not have a valid SSN for employment issued before the 2024 filing deadline (including extension), you cannot claim a child tax credit for that child.

To claim the excess for other dependents, the taxpayer's dependent family must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the 2024 tax filing deadline (including extended deadlines). Only students and trainees from India who are non-resident business owners may claim the excess for other dependents, as per Section 212 of the Income Tax Treaty with U.S. Nationals, Canadians, Mexicans, Resident Aliens, or Indian Residents.

However, as discussed in Section 1, if you are married and a U.S. citizen, or if you choose to file jointly with a spouse who is a resident alien, you may be eligible for this tax credit. If you and your spouse do not have an SSN issued on or before the 2024 filing deadline (including the extended filing deadline), you may not be able to claim the source income tax credit on your original or modified tax return for 2024.
You can claim the withholding tax during the year as a U.S. tax deduction on lines 25a and 25g of Form 1040-NR. The withholding tax reduces the tax you have to pay on Form 1040-NR.

Federal income tax withheld from wages and salaries of nonresident aliens is allowed as a payment of U.S. income tax liabilities for the same year. You may claim withheld income tax regardless of whether you engaged in a trade or business in the United States in that year and regardless of whether the salary (or other income) was related to a trade or business in the United States.

If you have two or more employers, you may be able to claim a tax credit for your U.S. income tax paid in excess of the required maximum Social Security tax, equal to the Social Security tax withheld. For more information, see the eight Social Security and Medicare taxes.

Your employer is required to withhold an additional Medicare tax of 0.9% (0.009) on Medicare payroll or Railroad Retirement Tax Act (RRTA) benefits that exceed $200,000 in 2024. If you do not have to pay the additional Medicare tax, you may file Form 8959 to claim a deduction for the additional Medicare tax withholding on your entire tax liability that appears on your tax return.

If you are a shareholder of a mutual fund (or other regulated investment company (RIC) or real estate investment trust (REIT), you can claim a tax credit for your share of the tax paid by the company on your paid long-term capital gains. You will be given information on Form 2439 which must be attached to your income tax return.

Fixed or determinable income includes interest, dividends, royalties, and royalty income that you do not claim to be materially linked to the income. Salary or wages may be fixed or determinable income to you, but generally, as discussed above, a withholding tax applies.

If you are an offshore partner of a partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the ECTI partnership income. The partnership will send you a tax return, Form 8805, showing the withheld tax. A public partnership may also withhold tax on the actual distribution of income that is substantially connected.

The rules for such withholding and payment are similar to those for U.S. real estate sales. If you receive a Form 8288-A reflecting the withholding amount, you will be required to report it on Form 1040-NR, line 25f, and claim it as a tax deduction for the withholding tax to be paid on the gain. You may also reduce or eliminate the withholding tax by providing certain information to the recipient, or by providing a source allocation. For example, if the withholding tax is required by the withholding tax provision of a particular state law and the withholding tax is generally applied to all the withholding tax provisions for the year in which the withholding tax is realized, the recipient will be required to provide a source allocation for the year in which the withholding tax is applied, as provided in Section 14 (f) of the IRS Notice No. 1446-2021 (TDIR 1446-119) (if you are not a taxpayer) and if you are not a taxpayer, you will be required to add the details in Section 14 (f) of the IRS No. 1446-2021 (TDIR 1446-119) (if you are not a taxpayer) and file it as a tax deduction on the withholding tax due date.

For disposal of a U.S. real estate interest (a gain deemed to be derived from the disposal of a U.S. real estate interest), taxes withheld may be reported as a payment. Please refer to the property gain or loss in section 4 above. The buyer will provide you with a certificate of withholding on 8288-A. Please report taxes withheld as a payment on line 25f of Form 1040-NR.

When you file a tax return, you should be especially careful to enter the correct amount of withholding tax on the information document. The following table lists some of the more common information documents and shows where to find withholding taxes.

Nonresident aliens who are actual residents of the U.S. territories of Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire taxable year in question are generally taxed in the same manner as resident aliens. They must file Form 1040 or 1040-SR and report all income from sources within the United States and outside of the United States, but may exclude income discussed in the following paragraphs. If you are a resident alien, you are considered a nonresident alien for purposes other than reporting income. For example, you are not allowed to file a standard deduction, you cannot file a joint return, and you cannot file a dependent family income tax return if the person is not a U.S. citizen, or a national. There is also a deduction and tax deduction allowance.

If you are a resident of Puerto Rico for the entire year, you may exclude all income from Puerto Rico sources from your total income (not the amount for service as an employee of the U.S. government or agency). If you have reported income as of the previous year and have no salary with withholding tax in 2024, you must file a return and pay taxes by June 16, 2025, and you must pay your first estimated tax for 2025, if you are not filing taxes or paying your estimated tax jointly, by June 16, 2025, and you are a U.S. citizen or married to a U.S. resident, please note that your nonresident spouse is considered a resident of Puerto Rico if you are a resident of Puerto Rico. If you earned a salary withholding tax applies, the filing deadline for filing your U.S. income tax return is April 15, 2025. If you have earned a salary withholding tax applies, you must pay your first estimated tax for 2025 by April 15, 2025. If you are a resident of Puerto Rico, you must check with your tax advisor for details on your first estimated tax return and tax deduction for the first eight years of your residence in Puerto Rico.

If you are a resident of American Samoa for the entire year in question, then you may exclude income from American Samoa sources from your total income (not the amount for services performed as an employee of the U.S. Government or an agency). For purposes of applying the exception, employees of the Government of American Samoa are not considered employees of the United States Government or an agency. For more information on the exception, see Form 4563 and Publication 570 (in English).

If you have established a regular accounting year (the last day of a month other than December or the last 12 consecutive months ending in 52-53 weeks) and are considered a resident of the United States in any previous year, you are considered a resident of the United States for part of the fiscal year in the current year.

If you are an individual who does not have an SSN or is ineligible to receive an SSN, you must apply for an individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN). If you are an individual who is engaged in a trade or business as a sole proprietor, or who has employees, or who has an eligible retirement plan, you are required to provide a taxpayer identification number. If you are a sole proprietor, you must provide a taxpayer identification number. If you are an individual who has income substantially connected with the conduct of a trade or business in the United States at any time during the year in question, an alien who has an office or place of business in the United States at any time during the year in question, an alien who is considered a resident of the United States at any time during the year in question, a nonresident spouse, or a taxpayer who files a tax return, amended return, or refund claim (but not an alien who files a return).

Generally, you can get an SSN if you have entered the United States legally as a permanent resident or if you have authorized employment in another U.S. state under the Immigration Act. If you do not have an SSN, contact the Social Security Administration (SSA) to find out if you are eligible. For more information, visit SSA.gov or call 800-772-1213 (if you are deaf or hard of hearing, call 800-325-0778).

If you are eligible for an ITIN and your application is complete, you will usually receive a letter from the IRS stating that the TIN has been issued within seven weeks. If you have not received an ITIN or other correspondence after seven weeks of filing, if you are in the United States, call the IRS recipient telephone number 800-829-1040 to check the status of your application. If you are abroad, call 267-941-1000 (or the newly assigned number).

Some ITINs are required to be renewed, such as those issued before 2013 that have expired and are required to file a 2024 tax return. If you have previously filed a renewal application and have been denied, you do not have to renew your ITIN unless you have used your ITIN at least once before, and you have not used your ITIN again on your federal tax return for the 2021 tax year.

Married non-resident aliens who are not married to a U.S. citizen or resident must use a tax slip or tax calculation worksheet for the individual couple's filing when determining tax on income substantially connected with a U.S. transaction or business.

Nonresident alien estates or trusts that use Form 1040-NR must use the tax rate schedule W of the Form 1040NR guidance when determining tax on income substantially connected to a U.S. transaction or business.

The income of each taxable item must be reported in accordance with the rules in Chapters 2, 3 and 4 of the Internal Revenue Code. For resident aliens, this includes income from all sources, domestic and foreign. Nonresident aliens include both income that is materially connected to a transaction or business in the United States (where a differential tax rate applies) and income of U.S. origin that is materially unconnected (where a fixed 30% or lower conventional tax rate applies).

Resident aliens and nonresident aliens may charge similar fees on their U.S. tax returns, but nonresident aliens generally only charge fees associated with income that is substantially linked to a transaction or business in the United States.

You may charge fees to calculate your actual connected taxable income (ECTI), but you may not charge fees related to income that is not generally associated with your business activities in the United States. Exceptions to the specific item-by-item fees, which will be discussed later, are limited to the extent of your actual connected income.

You may be reimbursed for all general and necessary expenses incurred in the operation of a business in the United States to the extent that they relate to income materially connected with the operation of the business. For information on other business expenses, please refer to the Guide to Business Expense Materials.

If you paid interest on a qualifying student loan in 2024, you may be eligible to deduct up to $2,500 of the interest you paid. Generally, if you meet all the tests, you may be eligible to deduct. You can deduct from Schedule 1 (Form 1040) line 21.

If you have income substantially connected to a U.S. transaction or business, you are entitled to a deduction of up to 20% of the income from the qualifying transaction or business, and an additional 20% of the income from qualifying REIT dividends and qualifying public partnership (PTP) income. For more details, see line 13a in the instructions on Form 1040-NR. For more details on the Eligible Business Income Tax, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A and its schedules, and the instructions on related forms and schedules.

Losses arising from transactions you entered into for profit, but which were not reimbursed by insurance or similar, are only eligible for deduction to the extent that they relate to income that is materially connected with the transaction or business in the United States.

If you were an eligible educator in 2024, you may be required to pay for certain professional development courses, books, supplies (other than non-physical supplies for health or physical education), computer equipment (including related software and services), and other assistive devices and materials used in classrooms in 2024, or to deduct from your income an adjustment for income up to $300 of the invariable qualifying expenses incurred. For more information, please refer to the instructions on the tax form. The qualifying expenses include the amount paid or incurred for personal protective equipment and other supplies used to contain the spread of coronavirus in 2024.

If you have made contributions to a traditional IRA in 2024, you are eligible to choose the IRA contribution, but you must have taxable benefits substantially linked to a U.S. transaction or business. You must send Form 5498 to the IRS by June 2, 2024, to prove your contributions to the IRA for 2024. If you are enrolled in a retirement plan (including 401K) through an employer or self-employment, your IRA contribution may be reduced or eliminated.

The price of the removal and storage services provided by the government does not include the income of the person, as the removal is for the purpose of complying with a military order for a change of station. Similarly, the amount received as a relocation allowance (DLA), temporary accommodation expenses, temporary accommodation allowance, or removal housing allowance is not included in the income of the person. For more information, see Publication 3 (English).

You must include all materially related interest income received by you or deposited in your account in the year in question as income. Do not deduct from this income any penalty payable for early withdrawals from a savings account. However, if the interest income was materially related to a U.S. transaction or business in the year in question, you may deduct the early withdrawal penalty imposed by a financial institution on Schedule 1 (Form 1040) line 17.

If you do not provide the SSN, ITIN, or Adoptive Parent Taxpayer Identification Number (ATIN) required by the Supporting Parents section of your tax return, or if you provide an incorrect number, certain tax benefits will be invalidated. Please refer to the previous identification number.

If you are a resident alien, your eligible dependent family includes your eligible child or eligible relative. To become your eligible child, you must pass five tests. To become an eligible relative, you must pass four tests. For more information, see the instructions on Form 1040. If you do not provide the SSN, ITIN, or ATIN of the dependent family required, or enter an incorrect number, certain tax benefits are waived.

If you are a Mexican Canadian resident alien or a U.S. citizen, you may claim a dependent relative for each of the families that meet certain tests. A Mexican, Canadian resident alien or U.S. citizen must determine a dependent relative using the same rules as a U.S. citizen. See Publication 501 (English).

Nonresident aliens who are residents of the Republic of Korea (other than employees of the DPRK government) or who are not a parent may claim their own children as eligible dependents. In addition to using the same rules as U.S. citizens to determine dependents, under the income tax treaty with the Republic of Korea, it is necessary that the nonresident alien's children have lived with the parent in the United States for some of the taxable years.
Students and corporate trainees who are eligible under Section 21 (2) of the US-Indian Income Tax Act can claim their dependents if they meet the same rules that apply to US citizens.

If you were an alien and a nonresident alien in the same year, you have dual taxation status. If you were married and chose to become a nonresident spouse who is considered a resident, as described in Chapter 1, the rules in this chapter do not apply to you in that year.

If you are a nonresident alien and you report your income on the basis of the last day of your taxable year and you receive a salary for which a withholding tax penalty is applicable, you must file your tax return on the last day of your taxable year or on April 15 of the next year after the end of your taxable year. If you report your income on a basis other than your taxable year, you must file your tax return on the 15th day of the fourth month following the end of your taxable year. If you do not receive your income on the basis of your taxable year, you must file your tax return on the 15th day of the fourth month following the end of your taxable year. If you do not receive your income on the basis of your taxable year, you must file your tax return on the 15th day of the fourth month following the end of your taxable year. If you do not receive your income on the basis of your taxable year, you must file your tax return on the 15th day of the fourth month following the end of your taxable year, using the address listed on the back of the instructions for Form 1040 and the address of the IRS, which is not the same as the last day of your taxable year, you filed tax return on the last day of your taxable year, and not the 15th day after the last day of your taxable year, you are not resident alien, you must file your tax return on April 15th day after the last day of your taxable year, or on April 15th day of your taxable year, or on the date of your last day of your taxable year, or the last day of your last day of taxable year, or the last day of taxable year, or the last day of your last day of taxable year, or the last day of your last day of taxable year, or the last day of your last day of taxable year, or the last day of your last day of taxable year, or your last day of taxable year, or the last day of your last day of your last day of tax year, or your last day of employment, or your last day of employment, or your last day of employment, or your last day of employment, or your last day of employment, or your last day of employment, or your last day of birth or your last day of employment, or your

If you have established a regular tax year (the last day of the month other than December or the last 12 consecutive months ending in 52-53 weeks) and are considered a resident of the United States for any previous year, you will be considered a resident of the United States for part of your tax year somewhere within the current year.

If you are a nonresident alien, then income from a U.S. source during the year in question and income from a specific foreign source that is considered to have a material connection with a transaction or business in the United States are taxable. If you are not a resident alien, then the rule that considers foreign source income to be income from a foreign source is not taxable if you were not a resident alien during the year in question. If you are not a resident alien, then the rule that considers foreign source income to be income from a foreign source is not taxable if you were not a resident alien during the year in question. If you are not a resident alien, then the rule that considers foreign source income from a material connection to your taxable income is not taxable if you were not a resident alien during the year in question. If you are not a resident alien, then any income from a source outside the United States that you earned while you were a resident alien is not taxable if you earned while you were a resident alien or if the income was earned during the year in which you were a nonresident alien or before the year in which you became a resident alien or a U.S. citizen is taxable. If you are a nonresident alien, then you are not subject to taxation. If you are not a resident alien, then you are not subject to taxation.
