If you file a tax return for a double tax deferral, the following restrictions apply:

If you are a dual-identity taxpayer, you may also claim dependents on your tax return. Generally, a dependent is a qualifying child or qualifying relative. If you have a qualifying dependent, you may be eligible to apply for additional deductions and deductions.

All income earned during the period of residence and all income substantially connected with a transaction or business in the United States during the period of non-residence is taxed at the rate applicable to U.S. citizens and residents after allowable deductions. Any income not connected with a transaction or business in the United States during the period of non-residence is taxed at a flat rate of 30% or a lower agreed-upon rate. No deduction is allowed for income.

During the year in which you were a nonresident alien, part of your Social Security and part of your equivalent Class 1 Railroad Retirement Benefits plus half of these benefits on adjusted gross income are taxed at a flat rate if the value is higher than a certain base amount. If you are not able to pay Social Security and equivalent Class 1 Retirement Benefits in the year in which you were a nonresident alien, you will be required to file with the Social Security Committee a tax return with the total tax and withdrawal amounts of the railroad retirement benefits for the year in which you were a nonresident alien, and send this tax return to the SSA-1042 and the SSA-1042 for your nonresident alien. Therefore, it is important to file with the SSA-1042 and the SSA-1042 for your nonresident alien for the year in which you were a resident alien, unless you received the RRB-1099 (RRB-1042), if you received the RRB-1099 and if you received the RRB-1099 during the period in which you were a nonresident alien, if you were not legally entitled to it, and if you were not paid the RRB-1042 if you were not legally entitled to it, then you are not required to file a separate tax return for the period in which you were a nonresident alien resident alien.

If you have paid income tax in a foreign country on income from overseas sources, or if you are liable for payment, you may be entitled to claim a deduction for overseas tax. If you claim a deduction for overseas tax, you must generally file Form 1116 with your income tax return. For more information, see the instructions for Form 1116 and Publication 514.

If you have paid someone to care for a dependent family member, a qualifying child under the age of 13, or a disabled dependent family member, or a disabled spouse, in order to work or seek employment, you may be eligible for this tax credit. As discussed in Chapter 1, married dual-identity aliens may only claim this tax credit if they choose to file jointly, or if they are specifically married individuals who do not live together.

The tax credit for non-dependent dependents is for those who do not have dependent dependents and are not eligible to apply for the child tax credit. Eligible dependents must be U.S. citizens, U.S. nationals, or U.S. resident aliens, and must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued prior to the 2024 filing deadline (including extended filings). See Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and the instructions for more information.

You may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for the qualifying costs paid to adopt a qualifying child. This amount may be allowed for adoptions of children in need of special care, regardless of whether there are qualifying costs. For an adoption tax credit request, please submit Form 8839 with your U.S. income tax return. If a married dual-identity alien has chosen nonresident spouse status that considers him or her a resident as discussed in Chapter 1, or if he or she qualifies as a specific married individual living separately (a married person who has not filed a joint return in the guidance for Form 8839), then this tax credit may be claimed.

You may report certain taxes paid or deemed to have been paid or withheld from income as tax payments on your U.S. income tax return. These include: taxes withheld from wages earned in the United States, taxes withheld from income from various items of U.S. source other than wages, estimated taxes paid with Form 1040-ES or Form 1040-ES (NR), and taxes paid with Form 1040-C when leaving the United States.
The U.S. income tax return that you must file as a dual-identity alien varies depending on whether you are a resident alien or a non-resident alien at the end of the tax year.

If you were a resident alien during the year and you are a resident of the United States on the last day of the tax year, you must file Form 1040 or 1040-SR. Please file a Dual-Status Return at the top of your income tax return. Attach a certificate to your income tax return showing your income for the year in which you were a nonresident.

If you gave up your residency in the year and are a dual-status taxpayer who is not a resident of the United States at the end of the tax year, you must file Form 1040-NR. If you have a dual-status return, you must file a Dual-Status Return at the top of your income tax return. If you have a certificate of income for the year in which you were a resident, you must attach it to your income tax return.

Resident aliens must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR at the address shown in the instructions for Form 1040 and Form 1040-SR. The filing deadline and tax due date is April 15 of the year following the year in which you file your tax return (see the previous tip). If you are a lawful permanent resident who is required to file a tax return under U.S. immigration law but fails to do so, you may be considered to have renounced your permanent residence status and may lose your permanent residence status.

If you want to claim overdraft, overpayment refund, or deductible or tax-deductible benefits, you must file a tax return. For example, if you have real estate income that you have chosen to be considered substantially connected income, but that you have not conducted business in the United States, as discussed in Chapter 4, you must file a true and accurate return in a timely manner in order to receive the allowable deduction for that income. For information on the definition of timely, see the timing of filing for deductions and tax-deductible benefits during the reporting period.

Even if you leave the United States and file Form 1040-C at the time of your departure, you still must file your annual U.S. income tax return. If you are married and you and your spouse are required to file, you must file separate returns.

If you are an employee and receive a salary that is subject to U.S. income tax withholding, you must generally file by the 15th day of the fourth month following the end of the taxable year. For the 2024 tax year, file by April 15, 2025. If you are not an employee whose salary is subject to U.S. income tax withholding, you must generally file by the 15th day of the sixth month following the taxable year. For the 2024 tax year, file by June 16, 2025.

The following allowable deductions are not affected by this time requirement: deductions for taxes withheld at source, deductions for excise taxes on the use of gasoline and special fuels, deductions for taxes paid on behalf of a mutual fund (or other RIC), or deductions for long-term capital gains paid by REITs.

If you believe that some of your activities in the United States have resulted in substantially linked income, you should provide a reason for filing this return. If you believe that some of your activities have resulted in substantially linked income, you should file a return that reports the public liability associated with that income until the regular period ends. To protect your right to collect tax credits and charges related to that income from other activities, you should also complete a statement that you are entitled to receive tax credits and charges related to your income even after the other activities have been determined to have resulted in substantially linked income. You should also complete a statement that you are entitled to receive tax credits and charges related to your income on the U.S. tax return if you believe that you are not responsible for the U.S. tax return.

If you fail to file a tax return when the IRS determines that you failed to file a tax return because of reasonable and intentional conduct consistent with the facts and circumstances of the case, and you cooperated with the IRS in determining your U.S. tax liability, the IRS may waive the tax filing deadline.
If you do not have a receipt for your payment, you may file Form 1040-NR with the Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center in Austin, TX 73301-0215.

For information on filing a U.S. Virgin Islands tax return, contact the IRS in the U.S. Virgin Islands. If you are a physical resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands and are temporarily working in the United States, you must pay income tax in the U.S. Virgin Islands and file an income tax return at the following address: Virgin Islands Bureau of Internal Revenue 6115 Estate Smith Bay Suite 225 St. Thomas, VI 00802 . This is the 8th address where you can discuss withholding taxes on your U.S. salary as a resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands.

You are a resident of Guam and are a resident of the United States of America. You are a resident of Guam and are a resident of the United States of America. You are a resident of the United States of America. You are a resident of the United States of America.

If you have to file Form 1040 or 1040-SR instead of Form 1040-NR, or vice versa, you should also use Form 1040-X. If you have amended Form 1040-NR or filed an accurate tax return, you should cross it out at the top and write Amended, and then attach the amended return (Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-NR) to Form 1040-X. Generally, the amended return claiming a refund must be filed within three years of filing your tax return or up to two years after the due date of your tax return.
You may be required to file a disclosure statement to report certain foreign income or assets or currency transactions.

If your total assets exceed the threshold, you must file Form 8938. The threshold depends on whether you live in the United States, are married, or filed a joint income tax return with your spouse. Specified foreign financial assets include financial accounts managed by a foreign financial institution, investments, stocks, bonds, or holdings in foreign companies, and financial instruments or contracts with non-U.S. parties or issuers. If you fail to file the required Form 8938, or you have a tax deduction for a transaction involving a private foreign asset, you may be required to pay a tax penalty. More information on filing Form 8938 can be found in the Form 8938 instructions.

For significant depreciation, only items that meet the requirements (or subsequent) of IRS Procedure 2024-44 as set forth in IRS.gov/irb/2024-52_IRB#REV-PROC-2024-44 are considered to be sufficiently disclosed in the return. IRS Procedure 2024-44 does not take into account the effective date of a tax law change enacted on a taxable year beginning after December 31, 2024. The line that mentions this tax procedure was affected by this change and if additional reporting is required, or if a rule or guideline for compliance or other regulations is issued, the line of Form 8275 or Form 8275-R must be filed to prove the disclosure of the rule.

If you file a tax return or other fraudulent filing, you may be subject to a $5,000 fine. A fraudulent tax return may not contain sufficient information to calculate the correct tax, or it may contain information that clearly proves that the tax you reported is substantially inaccurate. For more information on fraudulent tax returns, fraudulent filings, and a list of positions that have been found to be fraudulent, please see IRS.gov/irb/2010-17_IRB#NOT-2010-33 (or subsequent) if you have filed a fraudulent tax return or other fraudulent filing based on fraudulent tax returns or if you have submitted such returns or documents for the purpose of delaying or interfering with the administration of federal tax laws. This includes changing or deleting the language programmed on the space provided for your signature. This charge is added to the other penalties imposed by law.

If you do not include the required SSN or ITIN or someone else's SSN or ITIN in your return, statement, or other documentation, you may be subject to a $50 fine for each misdemeanor. If you do not disclose the required SSN or ITIN to someone else on your return, certificate, or other documentation, you may be subject to a $50 fine. For example, if you own a bank account with interest attached to it, you must provide your SSN or ITIN to the bank.

The term negligence includes failure to make a reasonable effort to comply with the tax law and to exercise general and reasonable care in compiling a return. Negligence also includes failure to keep a will and records. If you have a reasonable reason for the position you have taken or can prove reasonable cause and have acted in good faith, you may not have to pay a fine for negligence. The term negligence includes negligence, recklessness or wilful misconduct.

There are two types of continuous withholding tax: 1) withholding tax. If you are an employee, your employer will likely withhold income tax from your paycheck. Taxes are also withheld from certain other income, such as pensions, bonuses, commissions, gambling winnings, etc. The withholding tax is paid to the Treasury in your name.

Under these rules, if you are a nonresident alien, you must submit Form 8233 or Form W8BEN to your employer to prove that you are an alien or submit Form W-4 to prove that your salary is subject to a different tax rate at source than that of a resident alien or U.S. citizen. If you are a resident alien and you receive income from sources other than your salary in the United States (such as dividends, royalties, etc.), you must submit Form W-9 or a similar statement on behalf of the employer instead of the source of the original source (usually provided to the employee) to the employer so that the employee's agent does not have to pay additional taxes on the nonresident alien's income as a 30% (or lower) tax rate for the business, but as a taxable arrangement on the income of the nonresident alien, or Form W8BEN to the employer so that the foreign national can actually collect 30% (or lower) of the tax on the income of the business, if you are a resident alien and you receive a foreign national income taxable person.

The following discussion generally applies only to nonresident aliens. Taxes of resident aliens are withheld in the same manner as U.S. citizens. Salaries and other compensation paid to nonresident aliens for services performed as employees are taxed at the same rate as resident aliens or U.S. citizens, but at a different rate of withholding tax. Therefore, if your compensation is not legally excluded from the term "withholding tax", or is exempt by agreement, it is taxed at a different rate of withholding tax.

If you are an employee and receive a salary that is subject to secondary tax withholding, you will be required to complete Form W-4. Also, on Form 8233 (explained later in Income Qualifying for Tax Treaty Benefits), complete Form W-4 for past or present salary, future service, and scholarship or research grant payments for which you have not claimed tax treaty withholding exemption. This is a service that is required to be performed on you as an employee and on the condition that you receive a scholarship or grant (or a reduction in your tuition fees). Nonresident aliens must follow the special instructions in Publication 1392 (WEB when completing Form W-4 for compensation received as an employee who has performed non-independent personal services in the United States.
If you are eligible for the benefits of Section 21 (2) of the US-Indian Income Tax Act, you may claim additional withholding tax on the standard deduction.

If you worked as a household management employee, your employer is not required to withhold income tax. However, you may voluntarily consent to withholding income tax by submitting Form W-4 to your employer. If your employer accepts the consent by initiating withholding, the consent is effective. You and your employer may terminate the consent by notifying each other in writing.

If you are an H-2A agricultural worker, your employer may not withhold income tax from you. However, your employer will only withhold income tax if you and your employer agree to withhold it. In this case, you must submit a properly completed Form W-4 to your employer. More information on withholding taxes can be found at IRS.gov/ForeignAgriculturalWorkers.

Salaries that are exempt from U.S. income tax under income tax treaties are generally exempt from withholding taxes. For more information on how to apply for withholding tax exemption, see Income eligible for tax treaty benefits. Salaries paid to foreign nationals who are residents of the U.S. territories of Samoa, Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico, or the U.S. Virgin Islands may be exempt from withholding taxes.

If you are a resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico and are a nonresident alien employee, and are not an employee of a U.S. agency located in the United States or American Samoa or Puerto Rico, then wages for services performed in American Samoa and Puerto Rico are generally not subject to withholding tax.

Non-resident aliens who are actual residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands are exempt from U.S. withholding tax on income earned in temporary employment in the United States because they pay income tax in the U.S. Virgin Islands. To avoid withholding tax on income earned in the United States, a non-resident alien who is a resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands must send a copy of a letter to his or her employer stating that he or she is a resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands and expects to pay taxes on all income to the U.S. Virgin Islands.

If you receive a retirement pension distribution from the United States, this distribution is generally subject to a withholding tax of 30% (or a lower agreed rate). However, the portion of the pension arising from the performance of services in the United States after 1986 may be withheld at a secondary tax rate. You must complete Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 and submit it to the withholding agent or payer before any income is paid to you or credited to you.

Any tips received for services performed in the United States during the current tax year are subject to U.S. income tax. Include them in your taxable income. Additionally, if the tips received while working for one employer exceed $20 per month, a flat rate withholding tax is applied.

If you and the person to whom you provide services are not employees-employers, your pay is subject to a withholding tax at the agreed rate of 30% (or lower). However, if you are engaged in a transaction or business in the United States for tax purposes, your compensation for personal services as an independent contractor may be exempt from withholding tax in whole or in part if you agree with the IRS that the withholding tax is required. We hereby certify that an agreement with the IRS to withhold the withholding tax on an independent personal service is effective for the payments covered by the agreement after it has been substantially agreed by all parties. We hereby certify that you agree to file your withholding tax return on time.

If you are a nonresident alien who is a celebrity or an athlete who participates or participates in a sporting event in the United States, and you meet certain requirements, you may enter into an agreement with the IRS and the CWA for a reduced withholding tax. Under no circumstances may such withholding agreements reduce the tax withheld from you from the total amount of your anticipated income tax liability. Use Form 13930 to apply for a CWA for a nonresident alien celebrity or athlete whose total income in the United States is $10,000 or more as of the current date of the previous year.

If this information is sufficient, the IRS will determine the amount of provisional income tax on the total income substantially connected with the transaction or business in the United States for the year in question. The normal and necessary business expenses are eligible for consideration if the IRS Administrator or the IRS Administrator's designee has proven that they have been met. The IRS Administrator or the IRS Administrator's designee will send a letter to the tax collection agent showing the amount of the final payment of the exempt salary and the amount that may be paid to you by the tax collection agency. If it is appropriate, you must send two copies of this letter to the tax collection agent and attach a copy of the income tax return letter for the tax deduction in effect. For more information, see Publication 515 (in English).

If you are a distributor for a multi-level marketing company with erroneous withheld taxes, file a U.S. income tax return (Form 1040-NR or Form 1120-F) or, if you have already filed a tax return, file a refund claim (Form 1040-X or amended Form 1120-F) and recover the erroneous withheld amount. You must include, but not be limited to, items that include, but are not limited to, information that is required to be documented on your U.S. income tax return or refund invoice. Copy of Form W-2, Form 1042-S or Form 1099 to prove the amount of withheld tax. Copy of Form W-2, Form 1042-S, or Form 1099 to explain why the income reported on Form 1099 is not subject to tax. A statement of the reason why the U.S. income claim is not subject to tax. A statement of the reason why the income claim is not subject to tax. A statement of the reason why the income claim is not subject to tax. If you are a resident of the United States for more than one year, you must file a statement of the date of your first entry into or departure from the United States for tax purposes. If you are a multiple-age resident, this statement must be associated with the annual withheld amount of the withheld amount of the erroneously withheld amount withheld amount of the tax return, and the amount of the amount of the annual withheld amount actually withheld amount of the withheld tax claimed amount of the withheld tax, and less than one year during which your personal service was actually incurred in the United States (if you were not subject to the United States) less than one year of your personal service (less of your actual service (less of your annual service in the United States, less than one year of entry into the United States, less than one year of your first place of residence, if you were not registered, and less than one year, and less than one year, than one year, less than one year, than one year, less than one year, than the year, less than the year, less than the year, than year, less than year, than year, than year, than than than than than than than than than than than than than than than than than than than

For U.S. income tax purposes, green card holders are considered to be permanent residents of the United States unless their legal permanent residence status is revoked by immigration law or legally determined to be revoked by the administration. Please refer to the first green card test. If you are a green card holder and have an overseas address and your Social Security benefits were erroneously withheld from your Social Security benefits, the withheld tax will be refunded by the IRS. To receive a refund, you must file Form 1040 or 1040-SR. To verify that you are eligible for a refund, please send a return to the following address.

Other income subject to a withholding tax of 30% (or a lower agreed rate) generally includes the interest (not portfolio interest) discussed in Chapter 4, dividends, retirement pensions, pension distributions, income from certain sales and exchanges, and 85% of social security benefits paid to non-resident aliens.
The special rules for withholding tax on partnership income, scholarships, and research grants are explained below.

If you are an overseas partner of a U.S. or overseas partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your interest in the ECTI. Your partnership may reduce the withholding tax on your interest by taking into account certain partner-level deductions. Generally, for this purpose, you must file Form 8804-C. For more information, see the instructions on Form 8804-C. The withholding tax on your interest in the partnership's substantially connected income is generally the highest tax rate (37%) specified in Section 1. However, if you submit the appropriate documentation to the partnership, you may be able to withhold tax at the highest tax rate applicable to the particular type of income that you have been allocated.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner of a U.S. or overseas partnership engaged in a transaction or business in the United States (or deemed to be engaged in such), and have a benefit for the direct or indirect disposal of the interest thereon, for both types of income that occurred after 2017, the beneficiary will generally be required to withhold tax on 10% of the amount realized on the sale and pay it to the IRS on your behalf. The rules for such withholding and payment are similar to those for the sale of U.S. real estate interests. You will receive Form 8288-A reflecting the withholding amount and will be required to report it on line 25f of Form 1040-NR and claim it as a tax deduction for the non-interest income to be paid for this income. You may also reduce or eliminate the non-interest income on the basis of the direct or indirect disposal of the interest thereon by providing specific information to the beneficiary. For example, if the withholding income is not reported on the basis of a 10% of the income received by the beneficiary for the first month of the taxable income, the tax deduction for the non-income income received by the beneficiary is generally made by the beneficiary for the same tax year as the income received by the beneficiary, but the non-interest income is subject to the same tax deduction is made in accordance with the final with the income determined by the IRS, if you have not been taxed, in accordance with Section 1446 (F) and subsection (F) Section 1446 (F) of Section 14 (F (F) of the IRS Rule (F) (F (F) (F (F) (F) (F (F) (F) (F) (F (F) (F) (F) (F (F) (F) (F) (F (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F) (F

There is no withholding tax on qualifying scholarships received by a degree grant recipient. Please note that if you are a non-resident foreign student or grant recipient with one of the visas F, J, M, Q, and Q and received a grant or scholarship from a U.S. source that is not a full exemption, the withholding agent (usually the grant recipient) will withhold at a 14% (or lower) agreed tax rate on the taxable portion of the grant and scholarship, not the salary for the service. However, if you are not a degree grant recipient and the research grant meets certain requirements, the tax will be withheld at a 30% (or lower) agreed tax rate.
The sourcing agent may request that you fill out a Form W-4 and may choose to use an alternative procedure. See below for items that may reduce sourcing.
If you're a student who is eligible under Section 21 (2) of the American Indian Revenue Act, you can get a standard deduction, which is $14,600 in 2024.

If you have stayed in the United States for more than one tax year, you must attach a statement to Form W-4 proving that you filed a U.S. income tax return for the previous year. If you have not stayed in the United States long enough to be required to file a U.S. income tax return, you must attach a statement to Form W-4 stating that you will file a U.S. income tax return if required. If the principal receiver accepts your Form W-4 or uses the withholding tax return for the withholding tax on your salary as a source of income, please use this form to collect the tax on your income as a source of income.

If there is a tax treaty between the United States and your country of residence and your country of residence provides an exemption or a withholding tax rate on certain income items, you must declare your alien status to the taxpayer (the taxpayer's agent) to whom you are a resident in order to claim the tax treaty withholding tax exemption or the lower withholding tax rate. Generally, you do this by submitting to the taxpayer's agent either Form W-8BEN or Form 8233. For income other than personal service income, submit Form W-8BEN. For personal service income, which will be discussed later, submit Form 8233. If you are eligible for an exemption under the tax treaty but have not submitted Form 8233 to the taxpayer's agent to claim withholding tax, you may still be eligible for an exemption by filing Form 1040-NR. Follow the instructions on Form 1040-NR line 1a.

If you have provided personal services as an employee or independent contractor and you claim an exemption from withholding tax on personal service income because of a tax treaty, you must file Form 8233 with each withholding agent who will receive the amount. Even if you file Form 8233, the withholding agent may still have to withhold tax on your income because the factors on which the withholding tax is based cannot be determined until after the end of the tax year. If so, you must file Form 1040-NR to provide the IRS with proof that you are eligible for the exemption.

Students, teachers, and researchers should attach the appropriate statement from Appendix A (for students) or Appendix B (for teachers and researchers) at the end of the publication to Form 8233 and submit it to the withholding agent. For agreements not listed in the appendix, attach a similar form statement for other agreements. If you received scholarships or grants from the same withholding agent in addition to personal service income, use Form 8233 to claim withholding tax relief based on the tax treaty for both types of income.

A deduction of 30% of the total tax rate is required for amounts paid to non-resident aliens or foreign entities as admission fees (such as receipts for TV) for music festivals, boxing promotions, and other entertainment and sporting events, unless the withholding agent has received a specific instruction letter from the IRS. You may request a deduction of the withholding tax rate using Form 13930 for the year in which the total U.S. income occurred. You may also be required to withhold the withholding tax rate if the income in question is excluded from taxation by the terms of the tax treaty.

If the buyer knows that the certificate in (3) and (4) is not true or if he receives a notice from the seller or the buyer's agent (or substitute) that the certificate is not true, the buyer must disregard the certificate in (3) and (4); this also applies to the declaration of the qualified substitute in (4).
For information on the procedure for requesting withholding certificates, please see Publication 515 and IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Withholding-Certificates.

If you have a TIN, you must submit a copy of your tax return with your tax return. If your TIN is not listed on the form, the A-signed copy of Form 8288-A will not be provided to you. The IRS will send you a signature requesting the TIN and will provide you with an explanation of how to obtain the TIN. If you provide the TIN to the IRS, the IRS will provide you with a B-signed copy of Form 8288-A.

If you are an employee in the United States, you must pay Social Security and Medicare taxes in most cases. These taxes are paid to contribute to your coverage under the U.S. Social Security system. Social Security provides retirement benefits, survivor and disability benefits, and Medicare benefits to individuals who meet certain eligibility requirements in your case. In most cases, Social Security taxes will be applied to the first $168,600 of your overpaid salary received for services performed in the United States in 2024. All overpaid salaries are subject to Medicare taxes. Your employer deducts these taxes from each salary. Your employer must deduct these taxes from each salary, even if you do not expect to qualify for Social Security or Medicare benefits in the United States.

Your employer is required to collect additional Medicare tax at source of 0.9% (0.009) on Medicare salary or RRTA compensation in excess of $200,000. If you plan to file a joint return and you and your spouse are not expected to contribute more than $200,000 to your personal salary, but if your salary and your spouse's combined contribution to your personal income exceeds $250,000, you may request additional source compensation or estimated tax on your Medicare income on Form W-4 or Medicare Income. If you file Form 1040-NR, you must also check the IRS's guidance on the amount of your spouse's total and parental income for Medicare taxes on your Medicare salary or self-employment income in excess of $200,000 (see the IRS's Personal Income and Self-Support Tax Qualification page for additional information on whether you are a surviving spouse or self-supporting spouse). If you are a married couple, you must file Form 1040-NR. If you are not a surviving spouse, you must file Form 895-NR. If you are a married couple, you must file Form 1040-NR.

In general, services performed temporarily in the United States as a non-immigrant under subparagraphs (F), (J), (M), or (Q) of Section 101 (a) (a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act are not covered by the Social Security program if the services performed in the United States as a non-immigrant are for the purpose of entry into the United States. This means that the pay you received for those services does not include withholding of Social Security or Medicare taxes. These types of services are very limited and typically include work in the classroom, training, economic employment, etc. If you are considered a resident alien, as discussed in paragraph 1, your immigrant classification (F,J,M,Q) does not change, but your Social Security and Medicare taxes are withheld from your pay for these services. Social Security is provided by your spouse or child of a non-immigrant who is under the age of 18 years.

Exchanged visitors enter the United States temporarily under Section 101 (a) (j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Unless the exchange visitor is considered a resident alien, has received a work permit or a certified letter from a sponsor, the remuneration for services provided by the exchange visitor is not deductible from Social Security and Medicare taxes. If the services performed by the exchange visitor are not considered to have been performed for the purpose of the visitor's entry into the United States, the remuneration for services that are not exempt from remuneration under the tax law is deductible from Social Security and Medicare taxes.

If additional Medicare tax was withheld from your paycheck in error, you may file Form 8959 along with Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-NR to claim a deduction for additional Medicare tax withheld from the total tax liability that appears on your tax return. If additional Medicare tax was withheld in the prior year in which you mistakenly already filed Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-NR, you must file Form 1040-X for the prior year in which you received your paycheck or benefit and file the incorrectly withheld additional Medicare tax withheld.

Self-employment tax is a social security and Medicare tax on individuals who are self-employed.Non-resident aliens are not subject to self-employment tax unless it is determined that the self-employment tax is covered by the U.S. social security system.For this purpose, residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, the CNMI, or American Samoa are considered U.S. residents and are subject to self-employment tax.Information on the International Social Security Agreement is available at the end of this page.Resident aliens must pay self-employment tax under the same rules as citizens.However, income earned by resident aliens in the United States from work performed by an international organization, a resident alien, or an agency wholly owned by a foreign government is not subject to self-employment tax.Self-employment income received during your stay as a non-resident alien is subject to income tax for services performed as a resident alien.

If you have both a salary and self-employment income, the maximum amount of the additional Medicare tax applied to self-employment income is reduced (but not below 0) by the amount of the additional Medicare tax applied to the additional salary. Self-employment losses are not considered for the purpose of this tax. If you file Form 1040-NR, the total amount of your salary and self-employment income is $125,000 for married couples (check the couple-separate box at the top of page 1 of Form 1040-NR) and $200,000 for unmarried or eligible surviving spouses (check the unmarried or eligible surviving spouse box at the top of page 1 of Form 1040-NR).
If you have to pay self-employment tax, you can deduct a portion of the self-employment tax paid when calculating adjusted gross income, which is calculated on Schedule SE (Form 1040).

The United States has entered into a social security agreement with foreign countries, commonly called a Totalization agreement, to coordinate social security insurance and taxes for employees employed in one country for all or part of their career. Under this agreement, double insurance and double contributions for the same occupation are eliminated. This agreement generally specifies that social security taxes (including self-employment taxes) are only payable in one country. For a list of current international social security agreements, please visit SSA.gov/international/status.html. If additional agreements with countries are in effect, they will be posted on this website. For more information on international social security agreements, please visit SSA.gov/international/totalization_agreements.html.

Under this agreement, you or your employer must request specific assurance from the appropriate foreign agency. Generally, the appropriate agency will be the same as the one in which you or your employer paid overseas Social Security taxes. The overseas agency may tell you what information is required to issue the certificate. Your employer must keep a certificate proving that you are exempt from U.S. social security taxes, either on or after the effective date of the agreement.

Under most agreements, self-employed individuals are covered by the social security system of the country in which they reside. However, under some agreements, if you temporarily transfer your business activities to or from the United States, you may be exempt from U.S. self-employment tax. If you believe that your self-employment income is subject only to U.S. self-employment tax and is exempt from overseas social security, you may be able to request a certificate of insurance from the U.S. Social Security Administration (SSA) (see the link above). This certificate will prove that you are exempt from overseas social security tax.

If your adjusted gross income is $150,000 or more in 2024 ($75,000 if the taxpayer's portion of the 2024 taxable income is for a couple filing separately) and you are not engaged in agriculture or fishing, then apply 110% (1.10) instead of 100% (1.00) to (2) above. If you do not file a return in 2024, item (2) does not apply. Nonresident aliens must use Form 1040-ES (NR) to calculate and pay estimated tax. If you pay by check, you must have United States Treasury (U.S. Treasury) as the payee.

If you filed your 2024 tax return on Form 1040-NR and you expect your income and total expense for 2025 to be approximately the same, use your 2024 return as a guide to compose the estimated tax worksheet for your Form 1040-ES (NR) guideline. If you did not file your 2024 income tax return or your income, expense, or expense will be different in 2025, you must estimate this amount. Use the tax schedule in your 2025 Form 1040-ES (NR) guideline to calculate the estimated tax for your taxpayer breakdown.

If you are not required to pay estimated tax in April or June, you may have to pay estimated tax later because of a change in your circumstances. This may occur if you receive additional income or if some of the deductions are reduced or eliminated. In such cases, please refer to the Form 1040-ES (NR) Guidance and Publication 505 (English) for information on estimated tax calculation.

If the estimated tax has increased or decreased significantly because of a change in income or exemption after you have paid the estimated tax, you may adjust the remaining estimated tax payment. For this, see the Form 1040-ES (NR) Guidelines and Publication 505 (in English).

Expanded Special Rules and Reporting Procedures for Claims for Eligible Personal Disaster Losses Related to Disasters. The Taxpayer Certainty and Disaster Tax Relief Act of 2019 and the 2020 Taxpayer Certainty and Disaster Tax Relief Act of 2018 extended the scope of the Special Rules and Reporting Procedures for Personal Disaster Losses arising from disasters declared in 2018, 2019, and 2020. Eligible disaster losses incurred in the aforementioned tax year may be claimed on Form 4684. For more details, see, Eligible Disaster Losses in the future. If applicable, you may need to file an amended report using Form 1040-X to claim this benefit in the 2018, 2019, and/or 2020 returns.

This publication describes the tax treatment of losses resulting from disasters, theft, and loss of funds. Theft occurs when someone steals your property. Theft occurs when a financial institution defaults or goes bankrupt. The following topics are discussed in this publication: definition of losses resulting from disasters, theft, and loss of funds. How to calculate the amount of losses. How to process insurance claims and other claims received.

Publication 584, The Workbook for Personal Use Assets Lost in Accidents, Disasters, and Thefts, helps to compile a list of stolen or damaged personal use assets and identify losses. It includes a schedule to help identify losses of homes, interior furnishings, and automobiles. Publication 584-B, The Workbook for Business Use Assets Lost in Accidents, Disasters, and Thefts, helps to compile a list of stolen or damaged business or income-generating assets and identify losses.

When the three types of loss all refer to a federally declared disaster, the requirements for each loss are different. When a federally declared disaster is a disaster that the President of the United States decides to ensure the support of the federal government under the Stafford Act, a federally declared disaster may include (a) a major disaster declaration, or (b) a state of emergency declaration under the Stafford Act.

Disaster losses arise from a federally declared disaster, and are losses that occur in an assisted area under a presidential proclamation. Disaster losses must occur in counties where public or private assistance (or both) is available. Disaster losses are not limited to personal use assets, but can also be claimed for personal business or income-generating assets, and for corporations, S corporations, and partnerships. If you have suffered a disaster loss, you may be able to claim a disaster loss indemnity and use it to claim a loss in the immediate taxable amount. See Disaster Losses in Disaster Areas subsequently.

It is the sole responsibility of the plaintiff to bring the suit if the plaintiff is the victim of a major disaster declared by the President pursuant to Section 401 of the Stafford Act of 2016, Hurricane Harvey, Tropical Storm Harvey, Hurricane Emma, Hurricane Maria, and the California wildfires of January 2017 and 2018. It is the sole responsibility of the plaintiff to bring the case against the plaintiff for any major disaster declared by the President pursuant to Section 401 of the Stafford Act, occurring prior to December 21, 2018 and 2019, and not continuing after January 19, 2020 (except for the disaster caused by the California wildfires of January 2018, which is subject to mitigation measures), and the plaintiff is the sole victim of a major disaster declared by the President between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025, and the disaster is the cause of the disaster.

If you are an individual, then for tax purposes from 2018 to 2025, the disaster loss of personal use assets is only deductible to the extent of the loss arising from a federally declared disaster (federal disaster loss). Personal use assets are those assets that are not business assets or income-generating assets. If the event that causes the personal use asset loss (which is not caused by a federally declared disaster) occurred before January 1, 2018, but the loss did not occur until January 1, 2018 or later, then the personal use asset loss cannot be deductible.

The amount of personal injury loss suffered under this special procedure is not deductible from the federal disaster, and is therefore deductible only to the extent that the loss does not exceed the personal injury benefit. If the property has suffered a loss as a result of the walls of a particular import dryer installed in the home between 2001 and 2009, the amount of money paid to the home and its appliances for repairing damage caused by the drywall is less than the amount of money that was paid to the home during the taxable year in which the loss occurred. If the property has been damaged, the amount of money paid to the homeowner for repairing the damage caused by the damage is treated as a loss for the year in which the loss occurred.

For purposes of this special procedure, a "sub-standard drywall unit" means a drywall unit identified as a problematic drywall unit in accordance with the two-step identification method published by the CPSC and HUD in the Interim Guidelines for the Safety of Consumer Products (CPSC) and the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) as amended on January 28, 2010. The revised identification guidelines and improvements are available at CPSC.gov/en/Safety-Education/Safety-Education-Centers/Drywall-Information-Center.

The way you report your income depends on whether the asset is a business asset, an income-earning asset, or an interest-bearing asset.

If you adjust any of the base value adjustments described above, the amount you spend on repairs to restore the asset to its pre-disaster condition will increase the adjusted base value.

If you have questions about your taxes, or need help with filing a tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or instructions, visit IRS.gov to find resources that can help you immediately.

After receiving all salary and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment benefit statements (in either postal or digital format), or other government payment statements (Forms 1099-G), interest, dividend, and retirement statements (Forms 1099), from banks and investment companies, you can choose from several options for completing and filing a tax return: prepare a tax return yourself, check to see if you meet the eligibility requirements for a free return preparation agent, or hire a tax attorney to complete your return.

Taxpayers who need information about the helpline counseling service can call 833-690-0598. The helpline counseling service can answer questions about current and future helpline items and services in alternative media formats (e.g., dot, large, audio, etc.). The helpline counseling service cannot access your IRS account. For tax, refund, or account-related matters, please visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp.

To complete a mobile-friendly form that requires a signature, you must have an IRS Online Account (OLA) or an IRS e-mail address. You can submit the form online or download a copy and mail it to us. To certify your submission, you must scan the document. For more information, see IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms.

You can access information about your federal tax account securely at IRS.gov/Account. See your unpaid tax balances, sorted by year. See details of your payment plan or apply for a new payment plan. See your tax payments, your payment history for the last five years, and your current or scheduled payments. Access your tax records, including key data from your most recent tax return, your date of birth, and your age. See a digital copy of a select few IRS notices. Approve or reject an information approval request sent by a tax professional. Update your address or preferred method of contact.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information that can help you during tax season, including how to file your tax return, how to review your most recent tax return, and how to adjust your gross income. Create an account at IRS.gov/Account or log into your online account.

The quickest and easiest way to get a tax refund is to file electronically and choose Direct Deposit to securely and electronically transfer your refund directly to your financial account. Direct deposit avoids the possibility of being transferred due to checks being lost, stolen, lost, or undelivered by the IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers use direct deposit to get their refund. If you don't have a bank account, visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit to find out more about where to find banks or credit unions to open an online account with.

Direct File is a free service for taxpayers in participating states who have a relatively simple tax return that reports certain types of income and applies for certain tax credits and deductions. Direct File does not file a state tax return, but if you live in a participating state, it provides you with a state government support tool that you can use to write and file a state tax return for free. See IRS.gov/DirectFile for more details, program updates, and frequently asked questions. Free File is a free program that provides free advice to taxpayers who do not have the ability to file a personal federal tax return directly with the IRS, but also offers free tax advisory services for taxpayers who have completed a free tax return. IRS offers free assistance to taxpayers who are not eligible to file a tax return online by visiting IRS.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov/FileVita.gov.gov.

This includes your personal identification number (PIN), your password or credit card number, and similar information about your bank or other financial account. Please refer to IRS.gov/IdentityTheft for information about identity theft and data security for taxpayers, taxpayers, and businesses. We also provide information about what steps we take if we have lost or stolen our SSN, or we suspect that you are a victim of tax-related identity theft. We also provide information about how we protect our SSN. We also ask that you obtain our IP PIN. We provide us with our IP PIN, which is a six-digit number assigned to taxpayers to help prevent fraudulent use of our SSN on our tax returns. If we have our own PIN, we will inform you how we do it and we will help us prevent others from using our SSN to file our own tax returns. We also ask that you visit us. IRS.gov/IPPIN.

IRS.gov/SocialMedia (WEB) is a website that provides a variety of social media tools used by the IRS to share up-to-date information about tax changes, fraud alerts, initiatives, products, and services. Privacy and security are top priorities for the IRS. The agency uses these tools to share information with users and the public. Do not post SSN or other confidential information on social media sites. Always protect your identity when using social networking sites. The IRS YouTube channel provides short and useful videos on various tax-related topics in English, Spanish, and ASL.

For personal use assets, determine the amount of deductible loss that can be deducted by applying the deductible limit, which will be discussed later.

A disaster loss is not reduced by an insurance payment received to cover the cost of living in one of the following situations: the state's residence is unusable due to a disaster; the state's residence is not accessible by government authorities due to a disaster or the risk of a disaster.

Loans used to restore or replace assets that claim disaster loss compensation do not reduce disaster losses. If you have a canceled (amortized) federal loan, check the canceled federal loans from disaster area losses later.

If you have paid money for a private home repair with concrete foundation damage, you are the one who paid the money, or you are the one who paid the money on the original or modified return, and you (or the person who paid the money on your behalf) received the refund from the Connecticut Foundation Solutions Indemnity Company (CFSIC), you are the one who paid the refund, you must include a portion of the refund in your gross income.

If you receive a larger-than-expected refund later in the year after you filed for a loss allowance, you may be required to include the additional refund in your income for the year you received the refund. However, if the existing refund was not used at all to reduce your taxes for the previous year, you do not need to include part of the refund in your income. You do not recalculate your taxes for the year you filed for the allowance.
If you receive exactly the same amount of the refund that you expected to receive later, you don't have to include it in your income and you can't deduct any additional losses.

If the property was stolen and later recovered, the loss must be recovered using the adjusted base value (explained later) or the lesser of the FMV reductions from the time immediately before the theft to the time it was recovered. Use this amount to recover the total loss for the year in which the loss was incurred. If the recovered loss is less than the loss incurred, then generally the difference must be reported as income for the recovery year.

If you use the method of refuge described in IRS Procedure 2018-08 and are eligible, the IRS will not appeal your decision.

A private residential property is generally owned by an individual who has suffered a disaster and includes at least one private dwelling with improvements.A private residence is not included if the dwelling is used as a rental property or is part of a business or home office that is used for transactions or dealing in business or profit.For more information, please see Income Tax Procedures 2018-08.The methods of escape for private residential properties are as follows: (i) Expected repair methods; (ii) Minimum permitted expenses; (iii) Insurance methods; (iii) Federal Emergency Decree; (iii) Federal Emergency Decree; (iii) Federal Emergency Decree; (iii) Disaster Relief; (iii) Federal Emergency Decree; (iii) Disaster Relief; (iii) Federal Emergency Decree; (iii) Disaster Relief; (iii) Disaster Relief (iii) Disaster Relief (iii) Disaster Relief (iii) (iii) Disaster Relief (iii) (iii) Disaster Relief (iii) (iii) (iii) Disaster Relief (iii) (iii) (iii) Disaster Relief (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (iii) (

The estimated cost of repairs method is used to calculate the FMV reduction for private residential properties using the smaller of two repair estimates prepared by two separate and independent licensing agencies. The estimate must detail the item-by-item cost of restoring the property to its condition immediately before the damage occurred. The estimated cost of repairs method is limited to disaster losses of less than $20,000.

The minimum permitted refuge method is used to determine the FMV reduction for a private residential property based on a written good faith estimate of the cost of repairs required to restore the property to its pre-disaster condition. You should keep documentation showing how you have recovered the estimated loss amount. The minimum permitted refuge method is used for disaster losses under $5,000.

Using the insurance shelter method, you can determine the FMV reduction for a private residential property based on the expected loss in reports prepared by the homeowner or flood insurance company. These reports should state the expected loss you suffered due to property damage or destruction.

If the loss in the disaster area is due to a federally declared disaster, the relief provider method or the disaster loan assessment method may be used. Under the relief provider method, you may use the contract price for repairs specified in the contract prepared by an independent qualified provider to determine the FMV reduction for a private residential property. This method of relief is not applicable unless the individual contract is signed by you and the provider, and the provider specifies the item-by-item cost for restoring the private residential property to its condition immediately prior to the disaster.

Disaster loans can be determined by using sentiment assessments prepared to receive a federally declared disaster loss estimate or a federal government loan guarantee, which is determined by the Federal Disaster Relief and Emergency Relief Method, to determine the FMV reduction for private residential properties.

The cost of protecting assets from disaster or theft is not included in disaster or theft losses. The cost of taking out insurance or repairing a home for a storm is not included in losses. If the asset is a business asset, these costs are deducted as business expenses. If you are making permanent improvements to your property to protect it from disaster or theft, add the cost to the base value of the improvement asset.

Expenses incurred in connection with the qualifying disaster relief payments cannot be increased by the base value of the assets or deducted from the operating expenses (discussed in the Disaster Area Loss section below).

The loss of value of the property is not considered because the property is located in or near the area where the damage occurred or where the damage may occur again. Only the loss of the actual damage to the property is considered. However, if the home is in a federally declared disaster area, please note the disaster area loss later.

Generally, losses are calculated separately for each item that is stolen, damaged, or destroyed, but special rules apply to property owned for private use.

Personal loss is the loss of all non-property property that is lost or destroyed. If personal property is lost or stolen, or if there is personal injury or destruction, then the loss for each property must be separately identified. Then add these separate losses together to calculate the total loss, subtracting $100 from the total loss and 10% of AGI to calculate the loss allowance.

If both real estate and personal property are affected by a loss, you must account for the loss for each type of property separately, but only deduct $100 from the total loss, and then apply the 10% rule to determine the total loss for the loss.

If the asset is used for some personal purposes, some business or income generation, the disaster or theft loss formula should be calculated separately from the personal use portion and the business or income generation portion. The loss from these two uses is identified in two different ways, so each loss should be identified separately. When identifying each loss, allocate the total cost or base, the FMV, insurance or other reimbursement before the disaster or theft loss to the business and personal use assets. The $100 rule and the 10% rule apply only to the disaster or theft loss for the personal use portion of the asset.

If the principal residence was destroyed, then the beneficiary may exclude the benefit from income, as would be the case if the home was sold or exchanged, generally for a gain of up to $250,000 (and up to $500,000 for a joint declaration of the parties). To exclude the benefit, the beneficiary must have owned and lived in the property as the principal residence for at least two of the five years prior to the date of the destruction. For more information on the circumstances under which the principal residence was destroyed, see Publication 523. If the excess benefit is greater than the amount that can be excluded, but the replacement property is purchased, the excess benefit may be deferred.

In general, you must report the gain as income for the year in which you received the refund. However, if you meet certain requirements and choose to defer the return of the gain according to the rules described in the following deferral of the gain, you do not have to declare the gain. For more information on how to report the gain, please refer to the method of reporting the loss later. If you have a disaster or theft gain on a personal utility asset that you have chosen to defer, and you have another disaster or theft loss on a personal utility asset (as described below), then you should not consider the deferred gain when calculating the disaster or theft loss utility.

If you receive cash or other types of assets in exchange, you must generally report the gain on the stolen or destroyed assets. The Low Income Taxpayer Clinic (LITC) is independent of the IRS. The LITC represents individuals who have incomes below a certain level that require resolution of tax issues with the IRS, such as tax audit, filing of interest and tax collection disputes. In addition, the clinic may provide information about taxpayer rights and obligations in other languages for individuals who speak English as a second language. The service is free or for a small fee. To find a clinic near you, please visit TaxpayerAdvocate.com/LITCmap (WEB or see IRS Publication 4134, List of Low Income Taxpayer Clinics for more information about the taxpayer's tax deductions and tax credits.
